../block-storage/drivers/ibm-gpfs-volume-driver.rst:3 msgid "IBM GPFS volume driver" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/ibm-gpfs-volume-driver.rst:5 msgid "" "IBM General Parallel File System (GPFS) is a cluster file system that " "provides concurrent access to file systems from multiple nodes. The storage " "provided by these nodes can be direct attached, network attached, SAN " "attached, or a combination of these methods. GPFS provides many features " "beyond common data access, including data replication, policy based storage " "management, and space efficient file snapshot and clone operations." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/ibm-gpfs-volume-driver.rst:14 msgid "How the GPFS driver works" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/ibm-gpfs-volume-driver.rst:16 msgid "" "The GPFS driver enables the use of GPFS in a fashion similar to that of the " "NFS driver. With the GPFS driver, instances do not actually access a storage " "device at the block level. Instead, volume backing files are created in a " "GPFS file system and mapped to instances, which emulate a block device." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/ibm-gpfs-volume-driver.rst:24 msgid "" "GPFS software must be installed and running on nodes where Block Storage and " "Compute services run in the OpenStack environment. A GPFS file system must " "also be created and mounted on these nodes before starting the ``cinder-" "volume`` service. The details of these GPFS specific steps are covered in " "GPFS: Concepts, Planning, and Installation Guide and GPFS: Administration " "and Programming Reference." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/ibm-gpfs-volume-driver.rst:32 msgid "" "Optionally, the Image service can be configured to store images on a GPFS " "file system. When a Block Storage volume is created from an image, if both " "image data and volume data reside in the same GPFS file system, the data " "from image file is moved efficiently to the volume file using copy-on-write " "optimization strategy." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/ibm-gpfs-volume-driver.rst:39 msgid "Enable the GPFS driver" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/ibm-gpfs-volume-driver.rst:41 msgid "" "To use the Block Storage service with the GPFS driver, first set the " "``volume_driver`` in the ``cinder.conf`` file:" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/ibm-gpfs-volume-driver.rst:48 msgid "" "The following table contains the configuration options supported by the GPFS " "driver." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/ibm-gpfs-volume-driver.rst:53 msgid "" "The ``gpfs_images_share_mode`` flag is only valid if the Image Service is " "configured to use GPFS with the ``gpfs_images_dir`` flag. When the value of " "this flag is ``copy_on_write``, the paths specified by the " "``gpfs_mount_point_base`` and ``gpfs_images_dir`` flags must both reside in " "the same GPFS file system and in the same GPFS file set." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/ibm-gpfs-volume-driver.rst:61 msgid "Volume creation options" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/ibm-gpfs-volume-driver.rst:63 msgid "" "It is possible to specify additional volume configuration options on a per-" "volume basis by specifying volume metadata. The volume is created using the " "specified options. Changing the metadata after the volume is created has no " "effect. The following table lists the volume creation options supported by " "the GPFS volume driver." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/ibm-gpfs-volume-driver.rst:71 msgid "" "This example shows the creation of a 50GB volume with an ``ext4`` file " "system labeled ``newfs`` and direct IO enabled:" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/ibm-gpfs-volume-driver.rst:79 msgid "Operational notes for GPFS driver" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/ibm-gpfs-volume-driver.rst:81 msgid "" "Volume snapshots are implemented using the GPFS file clone feature. Whenever " "a new snapshot is created, the snapshot file is efficiently created as a " "read-only clone parent of the volume, and the volume file uses copy-on-write " "optimization strategy to minimize data movement." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/ibm-gpfs-volume-driver.rst:86 msgid "" "Similarly when a new volume is created from a snapshot or from an existing " "volume, the same approach is taken. The same approach is also used when a " "new volume is created from an Image service image, if the source image is in " "raw format, and ``gpfs_images_share_mode`` is set to ``copy_on_write``." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/ibm-storwize-svc-driver.rst:0 msgid "Description of IBM Storwise driver configuration options" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/ibm-storwize-svc-driver.rst:0 msgid "List of configuration flags for Storwize storage and SVC driver" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/ibm-storwize-svc-driver.rst:3 msgid "IBM Storwize family and SVC volume driver" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/ibm-storwize-svc-driver.rst:5 msgid "" "The volume management driver for Storwize family and SAN Volume Controller " "(SVC) provides OpenStack Compute instances with access to IBM Storwize " "family or SVC storage systems." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/ibm-storwize-svc-driver.rst:10 msgid "Configure the Storwize family and SVC system" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/ibm-storwize-svc-driver.rst:15 msgid "" "The Storwize family or SVC system must be configured for iSCSI, Fibre " "Channel, or both." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/ibm-storwize-svc-driver.rst:18 msgid "" "If using iSCSI, each Storwize family or SVC node should have at least one " "iSCSI IP address. The IBM Storwize/SVC driver uses an iSCSI IP address " "associated with the volume's preferred node (if available) to attach the " "volume to the instance, otherwise it uses the first available iSCSI IP " "address of the system. The driver obtains the iSCSI IP address directly from " "the storage system; you do not need to provide these iSCSI IP addresses " "directly to the driver." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/ibm-storwize-svc-driver.rst:28 msgid "" "If using iSCSI, ensure that the compute nodes have iSCSI network access to " "the Storwize family or SVC system." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/ibm-storwize-svc-driver.rst:33 msgid "" "OpenStack Nova's Grizzly version supports iSCSI multipath. Once this is " "configured on the Nova host (outside the scope of this documentation), " "multipath is enabled." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/ibm-storwize-svc-driver.rst:37 msgid "" "If using Fibre Channel (FC), each Storwize family or SVC node should have at " "least one WWPN port configured. If the ``storwize_svc_multipath_enabled`` " "flag is set to ``True`` in the Cinder configuration file, the driver uses " "all available WWPNs to attach the volume to the instance. If the flag is not " "set, the driver uses the WWPN associated with the volume's preferred node " "(if available), otherwise it uses the first available WWPN of the system. " "The driver obtains the WWPNs directly from the storage system; you do not " "need to provide these WWPNs directly to the driver." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/ibm-storwize-svc-driver.rst:49 msgid "" "If using FC, ensure that the compute nodes have FC connectivity to the " "Storwize family or SVC system." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/ibm-storwize-svc-driver.rst:53 msgid "iSCSI CHAP authentication" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/ibm-storwize-svc-driver.rst:55 msgid "" "If using iSCSI for data access and the ``storwize_svc_iscsi_chap_enabled`` " "is set to ``True``, the driver will associate randomly-generated CHAP " "secrets with all hosts on the Storwize family system. The compute nodes use " "these secrets when creating iSCSI connections." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/ibm-storwize-svc-driver.rst:69 msgid "" "Not all OpenStack Compute drivers support CHAP authentication. Please check " "compatibility before using." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/ibm-storwize-svc-driver.rst:79 msgid "Configure storage pools" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/ibm-storwize-svc-driver.rst:81 msgid "" "Each instance of the IBM Storwize/SVC driver allocates all volumes in a " "single pool. The pool should be created in advance and be provided to the " "driver using the ``storwize_svc_volpool_name`` configuration flag. For more " "details, see the configuration flags and how to provide the flags to the " "driver here: :ref:`config_flags`." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/ibm-storwize-svc-driver.rst:90 msgid "" "The driver requires access to the Storwize family or SVC system management " "interface. The driver communicates with the management using SSH. The driver " "should be provided with the Storwize family or SVC management IP using the " "``san_ip`` flag, and the management port should be provided by the " "``san_ssh_port`` flag. By default, the port value is configured to be port " "22 (SSH)." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/ibm-storwize-svc-driver.rst:99 msgid "" "Make sure the compute node running the cinder-volume management driver has " "SSH network access to the storage system." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/ibm-storwize-svc-driver.rst:102 msgid "" "To allow the driver to communicate with the Storwize family or SVC system, " "you must provide the driver with a user on the storage system. The driver " "has two authentication methods: password-based authentication and SSH key " "pair authentication. The user should have an Administrator role. It is " "suggested to create a new user for the management driver. Please consult " "with your storage and security administrator regarding the preferred " "authentication method and how passwords or SSH keys should be stored in a " "secure manner." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/ibm-storwize-svc-driver.rst:113 msgid "" "When creating a new user on the Storwize or SVC system, make sure the user " "belongs to the Administrator group or to another group that has an " "Administrator role." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/ibm-storwize-svc-driver.rst:117 msgid "" "If using password authentication, assign a password to the user on the " "Storwize or SVC system. The driver configuration flags for the user and " "password are ``san_login`` and ``san_password``, respectively." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/ibm-storwize-svc-driver.rst:121 msgid "" "If you are using the SSH key pair authentication, create SSH private and " "public keys using the instructions below or by any other method. Associate " "the public key with the user by uploading the public key: select the :" "guilabel:`choose file` option in the Storwize family or SVC management GUI " "under :guilabel:`SSH public key`. Alternatively, you may associate the SSH " "public key using the command-line interface; details can be found in the " "Storwize and SVC documentation. The private key should be provided to the " "driver using the ``san_private_key`` configuration flag." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/ibm-storwize-svc-driver.rst:131 msgid "Create a SSH key pair with OpenSSH" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/ibm-storwize-svc-driver.rst:133 msgid "You can create an SSH key pair using OpenSSH, by running:" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/ibm-storwize-svc-driver.rst:139 msgid "" "The command prompts for a file to save the key pair. For example, if you " "select ``key`` as the filename, two files are created: ``key`` and ``key." "pub``. The ``key`` file holds the private SSH key and ``key.pub`` holds the " "public SSH key." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/ibm-storwize-svc-driver.rst:144 msgid "The command also prompts for a pass phrase, which should be empty." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/ibm-storwize-svc-driver.rst:146 msgid "" "The private key file should be provided to the driver using the " "``san_private_key`` configuration flag. The public key should be uploaded to " "the Storwize family or SVC system using the storage management GUI or " "command-line interface." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/ibm-storwize-svc-driver.rst:153 msgid "Ensure that Cinder has read permissions on the private key file." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/ibm-storwize-svc-driver.rst:156 msgid "Configure the Storwize family and SVC driver" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/ibm-storwize-svc-driver.rst:159 msgid "Enable the Storwize family and SVC driver" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/ibm-storwize-svc-driver.rst:161 msgid "" "Set the volume driver to the Storwize family and SVC driver by setting the " "``volume_driver`` option in the ``cinder.conf`` file as follows:" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/ibm-storwize-svc-driver.rst:171 msgid "Storwize family and SVC driver options in cinder.conf" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/ibm-storwize-svc-driver.rst:173 msgid "" "The following options specify default values for all volumes. (``san_private_key``). If both are " "specified, the driver uses only the SSH private key." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/ibm-storwize-svc-driver.rst:266 msgid "" "The driver creates thin-provisioned volumes by default. The " "``storwize_svc_vol_rsize`` flag defines the initial physical allocation " "percentage for thin-provisioned volumes, or if set to ``-1``, the driver " "creates full allocated volumes. More details about the available options are " "available in the Storwize family and SVC documentation." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/ibm-storwize-svc-driver.rst:274 msgid "" "Defines whether thin-provisioned volumes can be auto expanded by the storage " "system, a value of ``True`` means that auto expansion is enabled, a value of " "``False`` disables auto expansion. Details about this option can be found in " "the ``–autoexpand`` flag of the Storwize family and SVC command line " "interface ``mkvdisk`` command." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/ibm-storwize-svc-driver.rst:281 msgid "" "Defines whether Real-time Compression is used for the volumes created with " "OpenStack. Details on Real-time Compression can be found in the Storwize " "family and SVC documentation. The Storwize or SVC system must have " "compression enabled for this feature to work." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/ibm-storwize-svc-driver.rst:287 msgid "" "Defines whether Easy Tier is used for the volumes created with OpenStack. " "Details on EasyTier can be found in the Storwize family and SVC " "documentation. The Storwize or SVC system must have Easy Tier enabled for " "this feature to work." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/ibm-storwize-svc-driver.rst:293 msgid "" "The driver wait timeout threshold when creating an OpenStack snapshot. This " "is actually the maximum amount of time that the driver waits for the " "Storwize family or SVC system to prepare a new FlashCopy mapping. The driver " "accepts a maximum wait time of 600 seconds (10 minutes)." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/ibm-storwize-svc-driver.rst:300 msgid "" "Multipath for iSCSI connections requires no storage-side configuration and " "is enabled if the compute host has multipath configured." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/ibm-storwize-svc-driver.rst:313 msgid "" "Defines whether or not the fast formatting of thick-provisioned volumes is " "disabled at creation. The default value is ``False`` and a value of ``True`` " "means that fast format is disabled. Details about this option can be found " "in the ``–nofmtdisk`` flag of the Storwize family and SVC command-line " "interface :command:`mkvdisk` command." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/ibm-storwize-svc-driver.rst:322 msgid "Placement with volume types" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/ibm-storwize-svc-driver.rst:324 msgid "" "The IBM Storwize/SVC driver exposes capabilities that can be added to the " "``extra specs`` of volume types, and used by the filter scheduler to " "determine placement of new volumes. Make sure to prefix these keys with " "``capabilities:`` to indicate that the scheduler should use them. The " "following ``extra specs`` are supported:" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/ibm-storwize-svc-driver.rst:330 msgid "" "``capabilities:volume_back-end_name`` - Specify a specific back-end where " "the volume should be created. The back-end name is a concatenation of the " "name of the IBM Storwize/SVC storage system as shown in ``lssystem``, an " "underscore, and the name of the pool (mdisk group). For example:" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/ibm-storwize-svc-driver.rst:340 msgid "" "``capabilities:compression_support`` - Specify a back-end according to " "compression support. A value of ``True`` should be used to request a back-" "end that supports compression, and a value of ``False`` will request a back-" "end that does not support compression. If you do not have constraints on " "compression support, do not set this key. Note that specifying ``True`` does " "not enable compression; it only requests that the volume be placed on a back-" "end that supports compression. Example syntax:" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/ibm-storwize-svc-driver.rst:353 msgid "" "``capabilities:easytier_support`` - Similar semantics as the " "``compression_support`` key, but for specifying according to support of the " "Easy Tier feature. Example syntax:" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/ibm-storwize-svc-driver.rst:361 msgid "" "``capabilities:storage_protocol`` - Specifies the connection protocol used " "to attach volumes of this type to instances. Legal values are ``iSCSI`` and " "``FC``. This ``extra specs`` value is used for both placement and setting " "the protocol used for this volume. In the example syntax, note ``<in>`` is " "used as opposed to ``<is>`` which is used in the previous examples." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/ibm-storwize-svc-driver.rst:373 msgid "Configure per-volume creation options" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/ibm-storwize-svc-driver.rst:375 msgid "" "Volume types can also be used to pass options to the IBM Storwize/SVC " "driver, which over-ride the default values set in the configuration file. " "Contrary to the previous examples where the ``capabilities`` scope was used " "to pass parameters to the Cinder scheduler, options can be passed to the IBM " "Storwize/SVC driver with the ``drivers`` scope." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/ibm-storwize-svc-driver.rst:381 msgid "" "The following ``extra specs`` keys are supported by the IBM Storwize/SVC " "driver:" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/ibm-storwize-svc-driver.rst:384 #: ../block-storage/drivers/ibm-storwize-svc-driver.rst:500 msgid "rsize" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/ibm-storwize-svc-driver.rst:386 #: ../block-storage/drivers/ibm-storwize-svc-driver.rst:502 msgid "warning" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/ibm-storwize-svc-driver.rst:388 #: ../block-storage/drivers/ibm-storwize-svc-driver.rst:504 msgid "autoexpand" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/ibm-storwize-svc-driver.rst:390 #: ../block-storage/drivers/ibm-storwize-svc-driver.rst:506 msgid "grainsize" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/ibm-storwize-svc-driver.rst:392 #: ../block-storage/drivers/ibm-storwize-svc-driver.rst:508 msgid "compression" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/ibm-storwize-svc-driver.rst:394 #: ../block-storage/drivers/ibm-storwize-svc-driver.rst:510 msgid "easytier" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/ibm-storwize-svc-driver.rst:396 msgid "multipath" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/ibm-storwize-svc-driver.rst:398 #: ../block-storage/drivers/ibm-storwize-svc-driver.rst:512 msgid "iogrp" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/ibm-storwize-svc-driver.rst:400 msgid "" "These keys have the same semantics as their counterparts in the " "configuration file. They are set similarly; for example, ``rsize=2`` or " "``compression=False``." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/ibm-storwize-svc-driver.rst:405 msgid "Example: Volume types" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/ibm-storwize-svc-driver.rst:407 msgid "" "In the following example, we create a volume type to specify a controller " "that supports iSCSI and compression, to use iSCSI when attaching the volume, " "and to enable compression:" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/ibm-storwize-svc-driver.rst:416 msgid "We can then create a 50GB volume using this type:" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/ibm-storwize-svc-driver.rst:422 msgid "Volume types can be used, for example, to provide users with different" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/ibm-storwize-svc-driver.rst:424 msgid "" "performance levels (such as, allocating entirely on an HDD tier, using Easy " "Tier for an HDD-SDD mix, or allocating entirely on an SSD tier)" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/ibm-storwize-svc-driver.rst:428 msgid "" "resiliency levels (such as, allocating volumes in pools with different RAID " "levels)" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/ibm-storwize-svc-driver.rst:431 msgid "features (such as, enabling/disabling Real-time Compression)" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/ibm-storwize-svc-driver.rst:434 msgid "QOS" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/ibm-storwize-svc-driver.rst:436 msgid "" "The Storwize driver provides QOS support for storage volumes by controlling " "the I/O amount. QOS is enabled by editing the ``etc/cinder/cinder.conf`` " "file and setting the ``storwize_svc_allow_tenant_qos`` to ``True``." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/ibm-storwize-svc-driver.rst:441 msgid "" "There are three ways to set the Storwize ``IOThrotting`` parameter for " "storage volumes:" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/ibm-storwize-svc-driver.rst:444 msgid "" "Add the ``qos:IOThrottling`` key into a QOS specification and associate it " "with a volume type." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/ibm-storwize-svc-driver.rst:447 msgid "" "Add the ``qos:IOThrottling`` key into an extra specification with a volume " "type." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/ibm-storwize-svc-driver.rst:450 msgid "Add the ``qos:IOThrottling`` key to the storage volume metadata." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/ibm-storwize-svc-driver.rst:454 msgid "" "If you are changing a volume type with QOS to a new volume type without QOS, " "the QOS configuration settings will be removed." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/ibm-storwize-svc-driver.rst:458 msgid "Operational notes for the Storwize family and SVC driver" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/ibm-storwize-svc-driver.rst:461 msgid "Migrate volumes" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/ibm-storwize-svc-driver.rst:463 msgid "" "In the context of OpenStack Block Storage's volume migration feature, the " "IBM Storwize/SVC driver enables the storage's virtualization technology. " "When migrating a volume from one pool to another, the volume will appear in " "the destination pool almost immediately, while the storage moves the data in " "the background." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/ibm-storwize-svc-driver.rst:471 msgid "" "To enable this feature, both pools involved in a given volume migration must " "have the same values for ``extent_size``. If the pools have different values " "for ``extent_size``, the data will still be moved directly between the pools " "(not host-side copy), but the operation will be synchronous." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/ibm-storwize-svc-driver.rst:478 msgid "Extend volumes" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/ibm-storwize-svc-driver.rst:480 msgid "" "The IBM Storwize/SVC driver allows for extending a volume's size, but only " "for volumes without snapshots." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/ibm-storwize-svc-driver.rst:484 msgid "Snapshots and clones" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/ibm-storwize-svc-driver.rst:486 msgid "" "Snapshots are implemented using FlashCopy with no background copy (space-" "efficient). Volume clones (volumes created from existing volumes) are " "implemented with FlashCopy, but with background copy enabled. This means " "that volume clones are independent, full copies. While this background copy " "is taking place, attempting to delete or extend the source volume will " "result in that operation waiting for the copy to complete." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/ibm-storwize-svc-driver.rst:495 msgid "Volume retype" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/ibm-storwize-svc-driver.rst:497 msgid "" "The IBM Storwize/SVC driver enables you to modify volume types. When you " "modify volume types, you can also change these extra specs properties:" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/ibm-storwize-svc-driver.rst:514 msgid "nofmtdisk" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/ibm-storwize-svc-driver.rst:518 msgid "" "When you change the ``rsize``, ``grainsize`` or ``compression`` properties, " "volume copies are asynchronously synchronized on the array." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/ibm-storwize-svc-driver.rst:524 msgid "" "To change the ``iogrp`` property, IBM Storwize/SVC firmware version 6.4.0 or " "later is required." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/ibm-xiv-volume-driver.rst:0 msgid "Description of IBM XIV and DS8000 volume driver configuration options" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/ibm-xiv-volume-driver.rst:3 msgid "IBM XIV and DS8000 volume driver" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/ibm-xiv-volume-driver.rst:5 msgid "" "The IBM Storage Driver for OpenStack is a Block Storage driver that supports " "IBM XIV and IBM DS8000 storage systems over Fiber channel and iSCSI." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/ibm-xiv-volume-driver.rst:9 msgid "" "Set the following in your ``cinder.conf`` file, and use the following " "options to configure it." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/ibm-xiv-volume-driver.rst:20 msgid "" "To use the IBM Storage Driver for OpenStack you must download and install " "the package. For more information, see `IBM Support Portal - Select Fixes " "<http://www.ibm.com/support/fixcentral/swg/selectFi xes?parent=Enterprise" "%2BStorage%2BServers&product=ibm/Storage_Disk/XIV+Storage+System+%282810," "+2812% 29&release=All&platform=All&function=all>`_." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/ibm-xiv-volume-driver.rst:26 msgid "" "For full documentation, see `IBM Knowledge Center <http://www.ibm.com/" "support/knowledgecenter/>`_." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/lenovo-driver.rst:0 msgid "Description of Lenovo volume driver configuration options" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/lenovo-driver.rst:3 msgid "Lenovo Fibre Channel and iSCSI drivers" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/lenovo-driver.rst:5 msgid "" "The ``LenovoFCDriver`` and ``LenovoISCSIDriver`` Cinder drivers allow Lenovo " "S3200 or S2200 arrays to be used for block storage in OpenStack deployments." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/lenovo-driver.rst:12 msgid "To use the Lenovo drivers, the following are required:" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/lenovo-driver.rst:14 msgid "Lenovo S3200 or S2200 array with:" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/lenovo-driver.rst:51 msgid "" "Verify that the array can be managed using an HTTPS connection. HTTP can " "also be used if ``lenovo_api_protocol=http`` is placed into the appropriate " "sections of the ``cinder.conf`` file." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/lenovo-driver.rst:58 msgid "" "Edit the ``cinder.conf`` file to define a storage back-end entry for each " "storage pool on the array that will be managed by OpenStack. Each entry " "consists of a unique section name, surrounded by square brackets, followed " "by options specified in ``key=value`` format." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/lenovo-driver.rst:63 msgid "" "The ``lenovo_backend_name`` value specifies the name of the storage pool on " "the array." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/lenovo-driver.rst:66 msgid "" "The ``volume_backend_name`` option value can be a unique value, if you wish " "to be able to assign volumes to a specific storage pool on the array, or a " "name that's shared among multiple storage pools to let the volume scheduler " "choose where new volumes are allocated." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/lenovo-driver.rst:82 msgid "**Example: iSCSI example back-end entries**" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/lenovo-driver.rst:104 msgid "**Example: Fibre Channel example back-end entries**" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/lenovo-driver.rst:124 msgid "" "If HTTPS is not enabled in the array, include ``lenovo_api_protocol = http`` " "in each of the back-end definitions." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/lenovo-driver.rst:127 msgid "" "If HTTPS is enabled, you can enable certificate verification with the option " "``lenovo_verify_certificate=True``. You may also use the " "``lenovo_verify_certificate_path`` parameter to specify the path to a " "CA_BUNDLE file containing CAs other than those in the default list." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/lenovo-driver.rst:137 msgid "**Example: [DEFAULT] section changes**" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/lenovo-driver.rst:147 msgid "" "Create a new volume type for each distinct ``volume_backend_name`` value " "that you added to the ``cinder.conf`` file. The example below assumes that " "the same ``volume_backend_name=lenovo-array`` option was specified in all of " "the entries, and specifies that the volume type ``lenovo`` can be used to " "allocate volumes from any of them." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/lenovo-driver.rst:154 msgid "**Example: Creating a volume type**" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/lenovo-driver.rst:167 msgid "" configuration options" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/lvm-volume-driver.rst:3 msgid "LVM" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/lvm-volume-driver.rst:5 msgid "The default volume back end uses iSER." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/lvm-volume-driver.rst:10 msgid "" "Set the following in your ``cinder.conf`` configuration file, and use the " "following options to configure for iSCSI ../block-storage/drivers/netapp-volume-driver.rst:0 msgid "Description of NetApp 7-Mode NFS driver configuration options" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/netapp-volume-driver.rst:0 msgid "Description of NetApp 7-Mode iSCSI driver configuration options" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/netapp-volume-driver.rst:0 msgid "Description of NetApp E-Series driver configuration options" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/netapp-volume-driver.rst:0 msgid "Description of NetApp cDOT NFS driver configuration options" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/netapp-volume-driver.rst:0 msgid "Description of NetApp cDOT iSCSI driver configuration options" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/netapp-volume-driver.rst:0 msgid "" "Description of extra specs options for NetApp Unified Driver with Clustered " "Data ONTAP" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/netapp-volume-driver.rst:3 msgid "NetApp unified driver" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/netapp-volume-driver.rst:5 msgid "" "The NetApp unified driver is a Block Storage driver that supports multiple " "storage families and protocols. A storage family corresponds to storage " "systems built on different NetApp technologies such as clustered Data ONTAP, " "Data ONTAP operating in 7-Mode, and E-Series. The storage protocol refers to " "the protocol used to initiate data storage and access operations on those " "storage systems like iSCSI and NFS. The NetApp unified driver can be " "configured to provision and manage OpenStack volumes on a given storage " "family using a specified storage protocol. Also, the NetApp unified driver " "supports over subscription or over provisioning when thin provisioned Block " "Storage volumes are in use on an E-Series backend. The OpenStack volumes can " "then be used for accessing and storing data using the storage protocol on " "the storage family system. The NetApp unified driver is an extensible " "interface that can support new storage families and protocols." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/netapp-volume-driver.rst:22 msgid "" "With the Juno release of OpenStack, Block Storage has introduced the concept " "of storage pools, in which a single Block Storage back end may present one " "or more logical storage resource pools from which Block Storage will select " "a storage location when provisioning volumes." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/netapp-volume-driver.rst:28 msgid "" "In releases prior to Juno, the NetApp unified driver contained some " "scheduling logic that determined which NetApp storage container (namely, a " "FlexVol volume for Data ONTAP, or a dynamic disk pool for E-Series) that a " "new Block Storage volume would be placed into." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/netapp-volume-driver.rst:33 msgid "" "With the introduction of pools, all scheduling logic is performed completely " "within the Block Storage scheduler, as each NetApp storage container is " "directly exposed to the Block Storage scheduler as a storage pool. " "Previously, the NetApp unified driver presented an aggregated view to the " "scheduler and made a final placement decision as to which NetApp storage " "container the Block Storage volume would be provisioned into." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/netapp-volume-driver.rst:42 msgid "NetApp clustered Data ONTAP storage family" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/netapp-volume-driver.rst:44 msgid "" "The NetApp clustered Data ONTAP storage family represents a configuration " "group which provides Compute instances access to clustered Data ONTAP " "storage systems. At present it can be configured in Block Storage to work " "with iSCSI and NFS storage protocols." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/netapp-volume-driver.rst:50 msgid "NetApp iSCSI configuration for clustered Data ONTAP" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/netapp-volume-driver.rst:52 msgid "" "The NetApp iSCSI configuration for clustered Data ONTAP is an interface from " "OpenStack to clustered Data ONTAP storage systems. It provisions and manages " "the SAN block storage entity, which is a NetApp LUN that can be accessed " "using the iSCSI protocol." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/netapp-volume-driver.rst:57 msgid "" "The iSCSI configuration for clustered Data ONTAP is a direct interface from " "Block Storage to the clustered Data ONTAP instance and as such does not " "require additional management software to achieve the desired functionality. " "It uses NetApp APIs to interact with the clustered Data ONTAP instance." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/netapp-volume-driver.rst:63 #: ../block-storage/drivers/netapp-volume-driver.rst:117 #: ../block-storage/drivers/netapp-volume-driver.rst:280 #: ../block-storage/drivers/netapp-volume-driver.rst:326 #: ../block-storage/drivers/netapp-volume-driver.rst:392 msgid "**Configuration options**" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/netapp-volume-driver.rst:65 msgid "" "Configure the volume driver, storage family, and storage protocol to the " "NetApp unified driver, clustered Data ONTAP, and iSCSI respectively by " "setting the ``volume_driver``, ``netapp_storage_family`` and " "``netapp_storage_protocol`` options in the ``cinder.conf`` file as follows:" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/netapp-volume-driver.rst:83 #: ../block-storage/drivers/netapp-volume-driver.rst:299 #: ../block-storage/drivers/netapp-volume-driver.rst:418 msgid "" "To use the iSCSI protocol, you must override the default value of " "``netapp_storage_protocol`` with ``iscsi``." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/netapp-volume-driver.rst:90 #: ../block-storage/drivers/netapp-volume-driver.rst:146 msgid "" "If you specify an account in the ``netapp_login`` that only has virtual " "storage server (Vserver) administration privileges (rather than cluster-wide " "administration privileges), some advanced features of the NetApp unified " "driver will not work and you may see warnings in the Block Storage logs." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/netapp-volume-driver.rst:98 #: ../block-storage/drivers/netapp-volume-driver.rst:232 #: ../block-storage/drivers/netapp-volume-driver.rst:306 #: ../block-storage/drivers/netapp-volume-driver.rst:354 #: ../block-storage/drivers/netapp-volume-driver.rst:425 msgid "" "For more information on these options and other deployment and operational " "scenarios, visit the `NetApp OpenStack Deployment and Operations Guide " "<http://netapp.github.io/openstack-deploy-ops-guide/>`__." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/netapp-volume-driver.rst:104 msgid "NetApp NFS configuration for clustered Data ONTAP" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/netapp-volume-driver.rst:106 msgid "" "The NetApp NFS configuration for clustered Data ONTAP is an interface from " "OpenStack to a clustered Data ONTAP system for provisioning and managing " "OpenStack volumes on NFS exports provided by the clustered Data ONTAP system " "that are accessed using the NFS protocol." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/netapp-volume-driver.rst:111 msgid "" "The NFS configuration for clustered Data ONTAP is a direct interface from " "Block Storage to the clustered Data ONTAP instance and as such does not " "require any additional management software to achieve the desired " "functionality. It uses NetApp APIs to interact with the clustered Data ONTAP " "instance." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/netapp-volume-driver.rst:119 msgid "" "Configure the volume driver, storage family, and storage protocol to NetApp " "unified driver, clustered Data ONTAP, and NFS respectively by setting the " "``volume_driver``, ``netapp_storage_family``, and " "``netapp_storage_protocol`` options in the ``cinder.conf`` file as follows:" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/netapp-volume-driver.rst:140 msgid "" "Additional NetApp NFS configuration options are shared with the generic NFS " "driver. These options can be found here: :ref:`cinder-storage_nfs`." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/netapp-volume-driver.rst:153 msgid "NetApp NFS Copy Offload client" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/netapp-volume-driver.rst:155 msgid "" "A feature was added in the Icehouse release of the NetApp unified driver " "that enables Image service images to be efficiently copied to a destination " "Block Storage volume. When the Block Storage and Image service are " "configured to use the NetApp NFS Copy Offload client, a controller-side copy " "will be attempted before reverting to downloading the image from the Image " "service. This improves image provisioning times while reducing the " "consumption of bandwidth and CPU cycles on the host(s) running the Image and " "Block Storage services. This is due to the copy operation being performed " "completely within the storage cluster." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/netapp-volume-driver.rst:164 msgid "" "The NetApp NFS Copy Offload client can be used in either of the following " "scenarios:" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/netapp-volume-driver.rst:167 msgid "" "The Image service is configured to store images in an NFS share that is " "exported from a NetApp FlexVol volume *and* the destination for the new " "Block Storage volume will be on an NFS share exported from a different " "FlexVol volume than the one used by the Image service. Both FlexVols must be " "located within the same cluster." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/netapp-volume-driver.rst:173 msgid "" "The source image from the Image service has already been cached in an NFS " "image cache within a Block Storage back end. The cached image resides on a " "different FlexVol volume than the destination for the new Block Storage " "volume. Both FlexVols must be located within the same cluster." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/netapp-volume-driver.rst:178 msgid "To use this feature, you must configure the Image service, as follows:" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/netapp-volume-driver.rst:180 msgid "Set the ``default_store`` configuration option to ``file``." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/netapp-volume-driver.rst:182 msgid "" "Set the ``filesystem_store_datadir`` configuration option to the path to the " "Image service NFS export." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/netapp-volume-driver.rst:185 msgid "Set the ``show_image_direct_url`` configuration option to ``True``." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/netapp-volume-driver.rst:187 msgid "Set the ``show_multiple_locations`` configuration option to ``True``." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/netapp-volume-driver.rst:189 msgid "" "Set the ``filesystem_store_metadata_file`` configuration option to a " "metadata file. The metadata file should contain a JSON object that contains " "the correct information about the NFS export used by the Image service, " "similar to:" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/netapp-volume-driver.rst:202 msgid "" "To use this feature, you must configure the Block Storage service, as " "follows:" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/netapp-volume-driver.rst:204 msgid "" "Set the ``netapp_copyoffload_tool_path`` configuration option to the path to " "the NetApp Copy Offload binary." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/netapp-volume-driver.rst:207 msgid "Set the ``glance_api_version`` configuration option to ``2``." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/netapp-volume-driver.rst:211 msgid "This feature requires that:" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/netapp-volume-driver.rst:213 msgid "The storage system must have Data ONTAP v8.2 or greater installed." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/netapp-volume-driver.rst:215 msgid "" "The vStorage feature must be enabled on each storage virtual machine (SVM, " "also known as a Vserver) that is permitted to interact with the copy offload " "client." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/netapp-volume-driver.rst:219 msgid "" "To configure the copy offload workflow, enable NFS v4.0 or greater and " "export it from the SVM." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/netapp-volume-driver.rst:224 msgid "" "To download the NetApp copy offload binary to be utilized in conjunction " "with the ``netapp_copyoffload_tool_path`` configuration option, please visit " "the Utility Toolchest page at the `NetApp Support portal <http://mysupport." "netapp.com/NOW/download/tools/ntap_openstack_nfs/>`__ (login is required)." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/netapp-volume-driver.rst:237 msgid "NetApp-supported extra specs for clustered Data ONTAP" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/netapp-volume-driver.rst:239 msgid "" "Extra specs enable vendors to specify extra filter criteria that the Block " "Storage scheduler uses when it determines which volume node should fulfill a " "volume provisioning request. When you use the NetApp unified driver with a " "clustered Data ONTAP storage system, you can leverage extra specs with Block " "Storage volume types to ensure that Block Storage volumes are created on " "storage back ends that have certain properties. For example, when you " "configure QoS, mirroring, or compression for a storage back end." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/netapp-volume-driver.rst:248 msgid "" "Extra specs are associated with Block Storage volume types, so that when " "users request volumes of a particular volume type, the volumes are created " "on storage back ends that meet the list of requirements. For example, the " "back ends have the available space or extra specs. You can use the specs in " "the following table when you define Block Storage volume types by using the :" "command:`cinder type-key` command." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/netapp-volume-driver.rst:259 msgid "NetApp Data ONTAP operating in 7-Mode storage family" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/netapp-volume-driver.rst:261 msgid "" "The NetApp Data ONTAP operating in 7-Mode storage family represents a " "configuration group which provides Compute instances access to 7-Mode " "storage systems. At present it can be configured in Block Storage to work " "with iSCSI and NFS storage protocols." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/netapp-volume-driver.rst:267 msgid "NetApp iSCSI configuration for Data ONTAP operating in 7-Mode" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/netapp-volume-driver.rst:269 msgid "" "The NetApp iSCSI configuration for Data ONTAP operating in 7-Mode is an " "interface from OpenStack to Data ONTAP operating in 7-Mode storage systems " "for provisioning and managing the SAN block storage entity, that is, a LUN " "which can be accessed using iSCSI protocol." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/netapp-volume-driver.rst:274 msgid "" "The iSCSI configuration for Data ONTAP operating in 7-Mode is a direct " "interface from OpenStack to Data ONTAP operating in 7-Mode storage system " "and it does not require additional management software to achieve the " "desired functionality. configuration options" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/nfs-volume-driver.rst:3 msgid "NFS driver" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/nfs-volume-driver.rst:5 msgid "" "The Network File System (NFS) is a distributed file system protocol " "originally developed by Sun Microsystems in 1984. An NFS server ``exports`` " "one or more of its file systems, known as ``shares``. An NFS client can " "mount these exported shares on its own file system. You can perform file " "actions on this mounted remote file system as if the file system were local." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/nfs-volume-driver.rst:13 msgid "How the NFS driver works" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/nfs-volume-driver.rst:15 msgid "" "The NFS driver, and other drivers based on it, work quite differently than a " "traditional block storage driver." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/nfs-volume-driver.rst:18 msgid "" "The NFS driver does not actually allow an instance to access a storage " "device at the block level. Instead, files are created on an NFS share and " "mapped to instances, which emulates a block device. This works in a similar " "way to QEMU, which stores instances in the ``/var/lib/nova/instances`` " "directory." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/nfs-volume-driver.rst:25 msgid "Enable the NFS driver and related options" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/nfs-volume-driver.rst:27 msgid "" "To use Cinder with the NFS driver, first set the ``volume_driver`` in the " "``cinder.conf`` configuration file:" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/nfs-volume-driver.rst:34 msgid "The following table contains the options supported by the NFS driver." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/nfs-volume-driver.rst:40 msgid "" "As of the Icehouse release, the NFS driver (and other drivers based off it) " "will attempt to mount shares using version 4.1 of the NFS protocol " "(including pNFS). If the mount attempt is unsuccessful due to a lack of " "client or server support, a subsequent mount attempt that requests the " "default behavior of the :command:`mount.nfs` command will be performed. On " "most distributions, the default behavior is to attempt mounting first with " "NFS v4.0, then silently fall back to NFS v3.0 if necessary. If the " "``nfs_mount_options`` configuration option contains a request for a specific " "version of NFS to be used, or if specific options are specified in the " "shares configuration file specified by the ``nfs_shares_config`` " "configuration option, the mount will be attempted as requested with no " "subsequent attempts." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/nfs-volume-driver.rst:54 msgid "How to use the NFS driver" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/nfs-volume-driver.rst:56 msgid "Creating an NFS server is outside the scope of this document." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/nfs-volume-driver.rst:59 msgid "Configure with one NFS server" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/nfs-volume-driver.rst:61 msgid "" "This example assumes access to the following NFS server and mount point:" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/nfs-volume-driver.rst:63 #: ../block-storage/drivers/nfs-volume-driver.rst:92 msgid "192.168.1.200:/storage" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/nfs-volume-driver.rst:65 msgid "This example demonstrates the usage of this driver with one NFS server." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/nfs-volume-driver.rst:67 msgid "" "Set the ``nas_ip`` option to the IP address or host name of your NFS server, " "and the ``nas_share_path`` option to the NFS export path:" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/nfs-volume-driver.rst:76 msgid "Configure with multiple NFS servers" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/nfs-volume-driver.rst:80 msgid "" "You can use the multiple NFS servers with `cinder multi back ends <https://" "wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Cinder-multi-backend>`_ feature. Configure the :ref:" "`enabled_backends <cinder-storage>` option with mutliple values, and use the " "``nas_ip`` and ``nas_share`` options for each back end as described above." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/nfs-volume-driver.rst:86 msgid "" "The below example is another method to use multiple NFS servers, and " "demonstrates the usage of this driver with multiple NFS servers. Multiple " "servers are not required. One is usually enough." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/nfs-volume-driver.rst:90 msgid "" "This example assumes access to the following NFS servers and mount points:" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/nfs-volume-driver.rst:93 msgid "192.168.1.201:/storage" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/nfs-volume-driver.rst:94 msgid "192.168.1.202:/storage" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/nfs-volume-driver.rst:96 msgid "" "Add your list of NFS servers to the file you specified with the " "``nfs_shares_config`` option. For example, if the value of this option was " "set to ``/etc/cinder/shares.txt`` file, then:" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/nfs-volume-driver.rst:107 msgid "Comments are allowed in this file. They begin with a ``#``." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/nfs-volume-driver.rst:109 msgid "" "Configure the ``nfs_mount_point_base`` option. This is a directory where " "``cinder-volume`` mounts all NFS shares stored in the ``shares.txt`` file. " "For this example, ``/var/lib/cinder/nfs`` is used. You can, of course, use " "the default value of ``$state_path/mnt``." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/nfs-volume-driver.rst:114 msgid "" "Start the ``cinder-volume`` service. ``/var/lib/cinder/nfs`` should now " "contain a directory for each NFS share specified in the ``shares.txt`` file. " "The name of each directory is a hashed name:" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/nfs-volume-driver.rst:125 msgid "You can now create volumes as you normally would:" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/nfs-volume-driver.rst:133 msgid "" "This volume can also be attached and deleted just like other volumes. " "However, snapshotting is **not** supported." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/nfs-volume-driver.rst:137 msgid "NFS driver notes" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/nfs-volume-driver.rst:139 msgid "" "``cinder-volume`` manages the mounting of the NFS shares as well as volume " "creation on the shares. Keep this in mind when planning your OpenStack " "architecture. If you have one master NFS server, it might make sense to only " "have one ``cinder-volume`` service to handle all requests to that NFS " "server. However, if that single server is unable to handle all requests, " "more than one ``cinder-volume`` service is needed as well as potentially " "more than one NFS server." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/nfs-volume-driver.rst:147 msgid "" "Because data is stored in a file and not actually on a block storage device, " "you might not see the same IO performance as you would with a traditional " "block storage driver. Please test accordingly." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/nfs-volume-driver.rst:151 msgid "" "Despite possible IO performance loss, having volume data stored in a file " "might be beneficial. For example, backing up volumes can be as easy as " "copying the volume files." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/nfs-volume-driver.rst:157 msgid "Regular IO flushing and syncing still stands." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/nimble-volume-driver.rst:0 msgid "Description of Nimble driver configuration options" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/nimble-volume-driver.rst:3 msgid "Nimble Storage volume driver" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/nimble-volume-driver.rst:5 msgid "" "Nimble Storage fully integrates with the OpenStack platform through the " "Nimble Cinder driver, allowing a host to configure and manage Nimble Storage " "array features through Block Storage interfaces." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/nimble-volume-driver.rst:9 msgid "" "Support for the Liberty release is available from Nimble OS 2.3.8 or later." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/nimble-volume-driver.rst:30 msgid "" "Enable encryption and default performance policy for a volume-type extra-" "specs" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/nimble-volume-driver.rst:35 msgid "" "The Nimble Storage implementation uses iSCSI only. Multipathing must be used to take advantage of these " "benefits." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/pure-storage-driver.rst:30 #: ../block-storage/drivers/xio-volume-driver.rst:23 msgid "Create a volume from snapshot." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/pure-storage-driver.rst:34 msgid "Create, list, update, and delete consistency groups." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/pure-storage-driver.rst:47 msgid "Configure OpenStack and Purity" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/pure-storage-driver.rst:49 msgid "" "You need to configure both your Purity array and your OpenStack cluster." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/pure-storage-driver.rst:53 msgid "" "These instructions assume that the ``cinder-api`` and ``cinder-scheduler`` " "services are installed and configured in your OpenStack cluster." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/pure-storage-driver.rst:57 msgid "Configure the OpenStack Block Storage service" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/pure-storage-driver.rst:59 msgid "" "In these steps, you will edit the ``cinder.conf`` file to configure the " "OpenStack Block Storage service to enable multipathing and to use the Pure " "Storage FlashArray as back-end storage." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/pure-storage-driver.rst:63 msgid "" "Retrieve an API token from Purity.
