The following " "sample ``/etc/cinder/cinder.conf`` configuration lists the relevant settings " "for a typical Block Storage service using a single Pure Storage array:" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/pure-storage-driver.rst:125 msgid "Replace the following variables accordingly:" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/pure-storage-driver.rst:128 msgid "" "Use either ``cinder.volume.drivers.pure.PureISCSIDriver`` for iSCSI or " "``cinder.volume.drivers.pure.PureFCDriver`` for Fibre Channel connectivity." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/pure-storage-driver.rst:130 msgid "PURE_VOLUME_DRIVER" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/pure-storage-driver.rst:133 msgid "" "The IP address of the Pure Storage array's management interface or a domain " "name that resolves to that IP address." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/pure-storage-driver.rst:134 msgid "IP_PURE_MGMT" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/pure-storage-driver.rst:137 msgid "" "The Purity Authorization token that the volume driver uses to perform volume " "management on the Pure Storage array." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/pure-storage-driver.rst:138 msgid "PURE_API_TOKEN" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/pure-storage-driver.rst:142 msgid "" "The volume driver automatically creates Purity host objects for initiators " "as needed. If CHAP authentication is enabled via the ``use_chap_auth`` " "setting, you must ensure there are no manually created host objects with " "IQN's that will be used by the OpenStack Block Storage service. The driver " "will only modify credentials on hosts that it manages." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/pure-storage-driver.rst:151 msgid "" "If using the PureFCDriver it is recommended to use the OpenStack Block " "Storage Fibre Channel Zone Manager." msgstr "" # #-#-#-#-# block-storage.pot (Configuration Reference 0.9) #-#-#-#-# # #-#-#-#-# compute.pot (Configuration Reference 0.9) #-#-#-#-# #: ../block-storage/drivers/quobyte-driver.rst:0 #: ../compute/config-options.rst:0 msgid "Description of Quobyte USP volume driver configuration options" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/quobyte-driver.rst:3 msgid "Quobyte driver" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/quobyte-driver.rst:5 msgid "" "The `Quobyte <http://www.quobyte.com/>`__ volume driver enables storing " "Block Storage service volumes on a Quobyte storage back end. Block Storage " "service back ends are mapped to Quobyte volumes and individual Block Storage " "service volumes are stored as files on a Quobyte volume. Selection of the " "appropriate Quobyte volume is done by the aforementioned back end " "configuration that specifies the Quobyte volume explicitly." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/quobyte-driver.rst:14 msgid "" "Note the dual use of the term ``volume`` in the context of Block Storage " "service volumes and in the context of Quobyte volumes." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/quobyte-driver.rst:17 msgid "" "For more information see `the Quobyte support webpage <http://support." "quobyte.com/>`__." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/quobyte-driver.rst:23 msgid "The Quobyte volume driver supports the following volume operations:" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/quobyte-driver.rst:25 msgid "Create, delete, attach, and detach volumes" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/quobyte-driver.rst:27 msgid "" "Secure NAS operation (Starting with Mitaka release secure NAS operation is " "optional but still default)" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/quobyte-driver.rst:30 msgid "Create and delete a snapshot" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/quobyte-driver.rst:38 msgid "Copy a volume to image" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/quobyte-driver.rst:40 msgid "Generic volume migration (no back end optimization)" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/quobyte-driver.rst:44 msgid "" "When running VM instances off Quobyte volumes, ensure that the `Quobyte " "Compute service driver <https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Nova/Quobyte>`__ has " "been configured in your OpenStack cloud." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/quobyte-driver.rst:51 msgid "" "To activate the Quobyte volume driver, configure the corresponding " "``volume_driver`` parameter:" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/quobyte-driver.rst:58 msgid "" "The following table contains the configuration options supported by the " "Quobyte driver:" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/scality-sofs-driver.rst:0 msgid "Description of Scality SOFS volume driver configuration options" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/scality-sofs-driver.rst:3 msgid "Scality SOFS driver" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/scality-sofs-driver.rst:5 msgid "The Scality SOFS volume driver interacts with configured sfused mounts." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/scality-sofs-driver.rst:7 msgid "" "The Scality SOFS driver manages volumes as sparse files stored on a Scality " "Ring through sfused. Ring connection settings and sfused options are defined " "in the ``cinder.conf`` file and the configuration file pointed to by the " "``scality_sofs_config`` option, typically ``/etc/sfused.conf``." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/scality-sofs-driver.rst:16 msgid "" "The Scality SOFS volume driver provides the following Block Storage volume " "operations:" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/scality-sofs-driver.rst:33 #: ../block-storage/drivers/vmware-vmdk-driver.rst:248 msgid "Backup a volume." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/scality-sofs-driver.rst:35 #: ../block-storage/drivers/vmware-vmdk-driver.rst:255 msgid "Restore backup to new or existing volume." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/scality-sofs-driver.rst:40 msgid "" "Use the following instructions to update the ``cinder.conf`` configuration " "file:" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/scality-sofs-driver.rst:57 msgid "Compute configuration" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/scality-sofs-driver.rst:59 msgid "" "Use the following instructions to update the ``nova.conf`` configuration " "file:" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/sheepdog-driver.rst:0 msgid "Description of Sheepdog driver configuration options" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/sheepdog-driver.rst:3 msgid "Sheepdog driver" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/sheepdog-driver.rst:5 msgid "" "Sheepdog is an open-source distributed storage system that provides a " "virtual storage pool utilizing internal disk of commodity servers." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/sheepdog-driver.rst:8 msgid "" "Sheepdog scales to several hundred nodes, and has powerful virtual disk " "management features like snapshotting, cloning, rollback, and thin " "provisioning." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/sheepdog-driver.rst:12 msgid "" "More information can be found on `Sheepdog Project <http://sheepdog.github." "io/sheepdog/>`__." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/sheepdog-driver.rst:15 msgid "This driver enables the use of Sheepdog through Qemu/KVM." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/sheepdog-driver.rst:20 msgid "Sheepdog driver supports these operations:" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/sheepdog-driver.rst:39 msgid "Set the following option in the ``cinder.conf`` file:" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/sheepdog-driver.rst:45 msgid "" "The following table contains the configuration options supported by the " "Sheepdog driver:" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/smbfs-volume-driver.rst:0 msgid "Description of Samba volume driver configuration options" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/smbfs-volume-driver.rst:3 msgid "SambaFS driver" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/smbfs-volume-driver.rst:5 msgid "" "There is a volume back-end for Samba filesystems. Set the following in your " "``cinder.conf`` file, and use the following options to configure it." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/smbfs-volume-driver.rst:10 msgid "" "The SambaFS driver requires ``qemu-img`` version 1.7 or higher on Linux " "nodes, and ``qemu-img`` version 1.6 or higher on Windows nodes." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/solidfire-volume-driver.rst:0 msgid "Description of SolidFire driver configuration options" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/solidfire-volume-driver.rst:3 msgid "SolidFire" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/solidfire-volume-driver.rst:5 msgid "" "The SolidFire Cluster is a high performance all SSD iSCSI storage device " "that provides massive scale out capability and extreme fault tolerance. A " "key feature of the SolidFire cluster is the ability to set and modify during " "operation specific QoS levels on a volume for volume basis. The SolidFire " "cluster offers this along with de-duplication, compression, and an " "architecture that takes full advantage of SSDs." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/solidfire-volume-driver.rst:12 msgid "" "To configure the use of a SolidFire cluster with Block Storage, modify your " "``cinder.conf`` file as follows:" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/solidfire-volume-driver.rst:25 msgid "" "Older versions of the SolidFire driver (prior to Icehouse) created a unique " "account prefixed with ``$cinder-volume-service-hostname-$tenant-id`` on the " "SolidFire cluster for each tenant. Unfortunately, this account formation " "resulted in issues for High Availability (HA) installations and " "installations where the ``cinder-volume`` service can move to a new node. " "The current default implementation does not experience this issue as no " "prefix is used. For installations created on a prior release, the OLD " "default behavior can be configured by using the keyword ``hostname`` in " "sf_account_prefix." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/solidfire-volume-driver.rst:37 msgid "" "The SolidFire driver creates names for volumes on the back end using the " "format UUID-<cinder-id>. This works well, but there is a possibility of a " "UUID collision for customers running multiple clouds against the same " "cluster. In Mitaka the ability was added to eliminate the possibility of " "collisions by introducing the **sf_volume_prefix** configuration variable. " "On the SolidFire cluster each volume will be labeled with the prefix, " "providing the ability to configure unique volume names for each cloud. The " "default prefix is 'UUID-'." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/solidfire-volume-driver.rst:46 msgid "" "Changing the setting on an existing deployment will result in the existing " "volumes being inaccessible. To introduce this change to an existing " "deployment it is recommended to add the Cluster as if it were a second " "backend and disable new deployments to the current back end." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/solidfire-volume-driver.rst:74 msgid "" "QoS support for the SolidFire drivers includes the ability to set the " "following capabilities in the OpenStack Block Storage API ``cinder.api." "contrib.qos_specs_manage`` qos specs extension module:" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/solidfire-volume-driver.rst:78 msgid "" "**minIOPS** - The minimum number of IOPS guaranteed for this volume. Default " "= 100." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/solidfire-volume-driver.rst:81 msgid "" "**maxIOPS** - The maximum number of IOPS allowed for this volume. Default = " "15,000." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/solidfire-volume-driver.rst:84 msgid "" "**burstIOPS** - The maximum number of IOPS allowed over a short period of " "time. Default = 15,000." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/solidfire-volume-driver.rst:87 msgid "" "The QoS keys above no longer require to be scoped but must be created and " "associated to a volume type. For information about how to set the key-value " "pairs and associate them with a volume type, run the following commands:" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/tintri-volume-driver.rst:0 msgid "Description of Tintri volume driver configuration options" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/tintri-volume-driver.rst:3 msgid "Tintri" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/tintri-volume-driver.rst:5 msgid "" "Tintri VMstore is a smart storage that sees, learns, and adapts for cloud " "and virtualization. The Tintri Block Storage driver interacts with " "configured VMstore running Tintri OS 4.0 and above. It supports various " "operations using Tintri REST APIs and NFS protocol." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/tintri-volume-driver.rst:10 msgid "" "To configure the use of a Tintri VMstore with Block Storage, perform the " "following actions:" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/tintri-volume-driver.rst:13 msgid "" "Edit the ``etc/cinder/cinder.conf`` file and set the ``cinder.volume.drivers." "tintri`` options:" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/tintri-volume-driver.rst:44 msgid "" "Edit the ``/etc/nova/nova.conf`` file and set the ``nfs_mount_options``:" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/tintri-volume-driver.rst:50 msgid "" "Edit the ``/etc/cinder/nfs_shares`` file and add the Tintri VMstore mount " "points associated with the configured VMstore management IP in the ``cinder." "conf`` file:" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/violin-v7000-driver.rst:3 msgid "Violin Memory 7000 Series FSP volume driver" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/violin-v7000-driver.rst:5 msgid "" "The OpenStack V7000 driver package from Violin Memory adds Block Storage " "service support for Violin 7300 Flash Storage Platforms (FSPs) and 7700 FSP " "controllers." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/violin-v7000-driver.rst:9 msgid "" "The driver package release can be used with any OpenStack Liberty deployment " "for all 7300 FSPs and 7700 FSP controllers running Concerto 7.5.3 and later " "using Fibre Channel HBAs." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/violin-v7000-driver.rst:16 msgid "To use the Violin driver, the following are required:" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/violin-v7000-driver.rst:18 msgid "Violin 7300/7700 series FSP with:" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/violin-v7000-driver.rst:20 msgid "Concerto OS version 7.5.3 or later" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/violin-v7000-driver.rst:22 msgid "Fibre channel host interfaces" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/violin-v7000-driver.rst:24 msgid "" "The Violin block storage driver: This driver implements the block storage " "API calls. The driver is included with the OpenStack Liberty release." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/violin-v7000-driver.rst:27 msgid "" "The vmemclient library: This is the Violin Array Communications library to " "the Flash Storage Platform through a REST-like interface. The client can be " "installed using the python 'pip' installer tool. Further information on " "vmemclient can be found on `PyPI <https://pypi.python.org/pypi/vmemclient/" ">`__." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/violin-v7000-driver.rst:56 msgid "" "Listed operations are supported for thick, thin, and dedup luns, with the " "exception of cloning. Cloning operations are supported only on thick luns." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/violin-v7000-driver.rst:63 msgid "" "Once the array is configured as per the installation guide, it is simply a " "matter of editing the cinder configuration file to add or modify the " "parameters. The driver currently only supports fibre channel configuration." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/violin-v7000-driver.rst:68 msgid "Fibre channel configuration" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/violin-v7000-driver.rst:70 msgid "" "Set the following in your ``cinder.conf`` configuration file, replacing the " "variables using the guide in the following section:" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/violin-v7000-driver.rst:84 msgid "Configuration parameters" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/violin-v7000-driver.rst:86 msgid "Description of configuration value placeholders:" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/violin-v7000-driver.rst:89 msgid "" "User defined capabilities, a JSON formatted string specifying key-value " "pairs (string value). The ones particularly supported are ``dedup`` and " "``thin``. Only these two capabilities are listed here in ``cinder.conf`` " "file, indicating this backend be selected for creating luns which have a " "volume type associated with them that have ``dedup`` or ``thin`` extra_specs " "specified. For example, if the FSP is configured to support dedup luns, set " "the associated driver capabilities to: {"dedup":"True","thin":"True" ""}." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/violin-v7000-driver.rst:96 msgid "VMEM_CAPABILITIES" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/violin-v7000-driver.rst:99 msgid "" "External IP address or host name of the Violin 7300 Memory Gateway. This " "can be an IP address or host name." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/violin-v7000-driver.rst:100 msgid "VMEM_MGMT_IP" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/violin-v7000-driver.rst:103 msgid "" "Log-in user name for the Violin 7300 Memory Gateway or 7700 FSP controller. " "This user must have administrative rights on the array or controller." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/violin-v7000-driver.rst:104 msgid "VMEM_USER_NAME" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/violin-v7000-driver.rst:106 msgid "VMEM_PASSWORD" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/violin-v7000-driver.rst:107 msgid "Log-in user's password." msgstr "" # #-#-#-#-# block-storage.pot (Configuration Reference 0.9) #-#-#-#-# # #-#-#-#-# compute.pot (Configuration Reference 0.9) #-#-#-#-# # #-#-#-#-# image-service.pot (Configuration Reference 0.9) #-#-#-#-# # #-#-#-#-# telemetry.pot (Configuration Reference 0.9) #-#-#-#-# #: ../block-storage/drivers/vmware-vmdk-driver.rst:0 #: ../compute/config-options.rst:0 #: ../image-service/image_service_backends.rst:0 #: ../telemetry/telemetry_service_config_opts.rst:0 msgid "Description of VMware configuration options" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/vmware-vmdk-driver.rst:0 msgid "Extra spec entry to VMDK disk file type mapping" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/vmware-vmdk-driver.rst:0 msgid "Extra spec entry to clone type mapping" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/vmware-vmdk-driver.rst:5 msgid "VMware VMDK driver" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/vmware-vmdk-driver.rst:7 msgid "" "Use the VMware VMDK driver to enable management of the OpenStack Block " "Storage volumes on vCenter-managed data stores. Volumes are backed by VMDK " "files on data stores that use any VMware-compatible storage technology such " "as NFS, iSCSI, FiberChannel, and vSAN." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/vmware-vmdk-driver.rst:14 msgid "The VMware VMDK driver requires vCenter version 5.1 at minimum." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/vmware-vmdk-driver.rst:17 msgid "Functional context" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/vmware-vmdk-driver.rst:19 msgid "" "The VMware VMDK driver connects to vCenter, through which it can dynamically " "access all the data stores visible from the ESX hosts in the managed cluster." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/vmware-vmdk-driver.rst:22 msgid "" "When you create a volume, the VMDK driver creates a VMDK file on demand. " "The VMDK file creation completes only when the volume is subsequently " "attached to an instance. The reason for this requirement is that data stores " "visible to the instance determine where to place the volume. Before the " "service creates the VMDK file, attach a volume to the target instance." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/vmware-vmdk-driver.rst:28 msgid "" "The running vSphere VM is automatically reconfigured to attach the VMDK file " "as an extra disk. Once attached, you can log in to the running vSphere VM to " "rescan and discover this extra disk." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/vmware-vmdk-driver.rst:32 msgid "" "With the update to ESX version 6.0, the VMDK driver now supports NFS version " "4.1." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/vmware-vmdk-driver.rst:38 msgid "" "The recommended volume driver for OpenStack Block Storage is the VMware " "vCenter VMDK driver. When you configure the driver, you must match it with " "the appropriate OpenStack Compute driver from VMware and both drivers must " "point to the same server." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/vmware-vmdk-driver.rst:43 msgid "" "In the ``nova.conf`` file, use this option to define the Compute driver:" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/vmware-vmdk-driver.rst:49 msgid "" "In the ``cinder.conf`` file, use this option to define the volume driver:" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/vmware-vmdk-driver.rst:56 msgid "" "The following table lists various options that the drivers support for the " "OpenStack Block Storage configuration (``cinder.conf``):" msgstr "" # #-#-#-#-# block-storage.pot (Configuration Reference 0.9) #-#-#-#-# # #-#-#-#-# compute.pot (Configuration Reference 0.9) #-#-#-#-# #: ../block-storage/drivers/vmware-vmdk-driver.rst:62 #: ../compute/hypervisor-vmware.rst:511 msgid "VMDK disk type" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/vmware-vmdk-driver.rst:64 msgid "" "The VMware VMDK drivers support the creation of VMDK disk file types " "``thin``, ``lazyZeroedThick`` (sometimes called thick or flat), or " "``eagerZeroedThick``." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/vmware-vmdk-driver.rst:67 msgid "" "A thin virtual disk is allocated and zeroed on demand as the space is used. " "Unused space on a Thin disk is available to other users." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/vmware-vmdk-driver.rst:70 msgid "" "A lazy zeroed thick virtual disk will have all space allocated at disk " "creation. This reserves the entire disk space, so it is not available to " "other users at any time." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/vmware-vmdk-driver.rst:74 msgid "" "An eager zeroed thick virtual disk is similar to a lazy zeroed thick disk, " "in that the entire disk is allocated at creation. However, in this type, any " "previous data will be wiped clean on the disk before the write. This can " "mean that the disk will take longer to create, but can also prevent issues " "with stale data on physical media." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/vmware-vmdk-driver.rst:80 msgid "" "Use the ``vmware:vmdk_type`` extra spec key with the appropriate value to " "specify the VMDK disk file type. This table shows the mapping between the " "extra spec entry and the VMDK disk file type:" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/vmware-vmdk-driver.rst:87 msgid "Disk file type" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/vmware-vmdk-driver.rst:88 #: ../block-storage/drivers/vmware-vmdk-driver.rst:125 msgid "Extra spec key" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/vmware-vmdk-driver.rst:89 #: ../block-storage/drivers/vmware-vmdk-driver.rst:126 msgid "Extra spec value" msgstr "" # #-#-#-#-# block-storage.pot (Configuration Reference 0.9) #-#-#-#-# # #-#-#-#-# compute.pot (Configuration Reference 0.9) #-#-#-#-# #: ../block-storage/drivers/vmware-vmdk-driver.rst:90 #: ../compute/hypervisor-vmware.rst:514 msgid "thin" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/vmware-vmdk-driver.rst:91 #: ../block-storage/drivers/vmware-vmdk-driver.rst:94 #: ../block-storage/drivers/vmware-vmdk-driver.rst:97 msgid "``vmware:vmdk_type``" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/vmware-vmdk-driver.rst:93 msgid "lazyZeroedThick" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/vmware-vmdk-driver.rst:96 msgid "eagerZeroedThick" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/vmware-vmdk-driver.rst:98 msgid "``eagerZeroedThick``" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/vmware-vmdk-driver.rst:100 msgid "" "If you do not specify a ``vmdk_type`` extra spec entry, the disk file type " "will default to ``thin``." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/vmware-vmdk-driver.rst:103 msgid "" "The following example shows how to create a ``lazyZeroedThick`` VMDK volume " "by using the appropriate ``vmdk_type``:" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/vmware-vmdk-driver.rst:113 #: ../block-storage/drivers/vmware-vmdk-driver.rst:124 msgid "Clone type" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/vmware-vmdk-driver.rst:115 msgid "" "With the VMware VMDK drivers, you can create a volume from another source " "volume or a snapshot point. The VMware vCenter VMDK driver supports the " "``full`` and ``linked/fast`` clone types. Use the ``vmware:clone_type`` " "extra spec key to specify the clone type. The following table captures the " "mapping for clone types:" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/vmware-vmdk-driver.rst:127 msgid "full" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/vmware-vmdk-driver.rst:128 #: ../block-storage/drivers/vmware-vmdk-driver.rst:131 msgid "``vmware:clone_type``" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/vmware-vmdk-driver.rst:129 msgid "``full``" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/vmware-vmdk-driver.rst:130 msgid "linked/fast" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/vmware-vmdk-driver.rst:132 msgid "``linked``" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/vmware-vmdk-driver.rst:134 msgid "If you do not specify the clone type, the default is ``full``." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/vmware-vmdk-driver.rst:136 msgid "" "The following example shows linked cloning from a source volume, which is " "created from an image:" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/vmware-vmdk-driver.rst:149 msgid "Use vCenter storage policies to specify back-end data stores" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/vmware-vmdk-driver.rst:151 msgid "" "This section describes how to configure back-end data stores using storage " "policies. In vCenter 5.5 and greater, you can create one or more storage " "policies and expose them as a Block Storage volume-type to a vmdk volume. " "The storage policies are exposed to the vmdk driver through the extra spec " "property with the ``vmware:storage_profile`` key." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/vmware-vmdk-driver.rst:157 msgid "" "For example, assume a storage policy in vCenter named ``gold_policy.`` and a " "Block Storage volume type named ``vol1`` with the extra spec key ``vmware:" "storage_profile`` set to the value ``gold_policy``. Any Block Storage volume " "creation that uses the ``vol1`` volume type places the volume only in data " "stores that match the ``gold_policy`` storage policy." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/vmware-vmdk-driver.rst:163 msgid "" "The Block Storage back-end configuration for vSphere data stores is " "automatically determined based on the vCenter configuration. If you " "configure a connection to connect to vCenter version 5.5 or later in the " "``cinder.conf`` file, the use of storage policies to configure back-end data " "stores is automatically supported." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/vmware-vmdk-driver.rst:171 msgid "" "You must configure any data stores that you configure for the Block Storage " "service for the Compute service." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/vmware-vmdk-driver.rst:174 msgid "**To configure back-end data stores by using storage policies**" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/vmware-vmdk-driver.rst:176 msgid "In vCenter, tag the data stores to be used for the back end." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/vmware-vmdk-driver.rst:178 msgid "" "OpenStack also supports policies that are created by using vendor-specific " "capabilities; for example vSAN-specific storage policies." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/vmware-vmdk-driver.rst:183 msgid "" "The tag value serves as the policy. For details, see :ref:`vmware-spbm`." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/vmware-vmdk-driver.rst:185 msgid "" "Set the extra spec key ``vmware:storage_profile`` in the desired Block " "Storage volume types to the policy name that you created in the previous " "step." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/vmware-vmdk-driver.rst:189 msgid "" "Optionally, for the ``vmware_host_version`` parameter, enter the version " "number of your vSphere platform. For example, ``5.5``." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/vmware-vmdk-driver.rst:192 msgid "" "This setting overrides the default location for the corresponding WSDL file. " "Among other scenarios, you can use this setting to prevent WSDL error " "messages during the development phase or to work with a newer version of " "vCenter." msgstr "" # #-#-#-#-# block-storage.pot (Configuration Reference 0.9) #-#-#-#-# # #-#-#-#-# image-service.pot (Configuration Reference 0.9) #-#-#-#-# #: ../block-storage/drivers/vmware-vmdk-driver.rst:197 #: ../image-service/image_service_backends.rst:129 msgid "Complete the other vCenter configuration parameters as appropriate." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/vmware-vmdk-driver.rst:201 msgid "" "Any volume that is created without an associated policy (that is to say, " "without an associated volume type that specifies ``vmware:storage_profile`` " "extra spec), there is no policy-based placement for that volume." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/vmware-vmdk-driver.rst:208 msgid "The VMware vCenter VMDK driver supports these operations:" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/vmware-vmdk-driver.rst:214 msgid "" "When a volume is attached to an instance, a reconfigure operation is " "performed on the instance to add the volume's VMDK to it. The user must " "manually rescan and mount the device from within the guest operating system." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/vmware-vmdk-driver.rst:223 msgid "Allowed only if volume is not attached to an instance." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/vmware-vmdk-driver.rst:231 msgid "" "Only images in ``vmdk`` disk format with ``bare`` container format are " "supported. The ``vmware_disktype`` property of the image can be " "``preallocated``, ``sparse``, ``streamOptimized`` or ``thin``." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/vmware-vmdk-driver.rst:239 msgid "Allowed only if the volume is not attached to an instance." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/vmware-vmdk-driver.rst:240 msgid "This operation creates a ``streamOptimized`` disk image." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/vmware-vmdk-driver.rst:246 msgid "Supported only if the source volume is not attached to an instance." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/vmware-vmdk-driver.rst:252 msgid "" "This operation creates a backup of the volume in ``streamOptimized`` disk " "format." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/vmware-vmdk-driver.rst:259 msgid "Supported only if the existing volume doesn't contain snapshots." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/vmware-vmdk-driver.rst:261 msgid "Change the type of a volume." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/vmware-vmdk-driver.rst:265 msgid "This operation is supported only if the volume state is ``available``." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/vmware-vmdk-driver.rst:273 msgid "Storage policy-based configuration in vCenter" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/vmware-vmdk-driver.rst:275 msgid "" "You can configure Storage Policy-Based Management (SPBM) profiles for " "vCenter data stores supporting the Compute, Image service, and Block Storage " "components of an OpenStack implementation." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/vmware-vmdk-driver.rst:279 msgid "" "In a vSphere OpenStack deployment, SPBM enables you to delegate several data " "stores for storage, which reduces the risk of running out of storage space. " "The policy logic selects the data store based on accessibility and available " "storage space." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/vmware-vmdk-driver.rst:285 msgid "Prerequisites" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/vmware-vmdk-driver.rst:287 msgid "Determine the data stores to be used by the SPBM policy." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/vmware-vmdk-driver.rst:289 msgid "" "Determine the tag that identifies the data stores in the OpenStack component " "configuration." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/vmware-vmdk-driver.rst:292 msgid "" "Create separate policies or sets of data stores for separate OpenStack " "components." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/vmware-vmdk-driver.rst:296 msgid "Create storage policies in vCenter" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/vmware-vmdk-driver.rst:298 msgid "In vCenter, create the tag that identifies the data stores:" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/vmware-vmdk-driver.rst:300 msgid "From the :guilabel:`Home` screen, click :guilabel:`Tags`." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/vmware-vmdk-driver.rst:302 msgid "Specify a name for the tag." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/vmware-vmdk-driver.rst:304 msgid "Specify a tag category. For example, ``spbm-cinder``." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/vmware-vmdk-driver.rst:306 msgid "Apply the tag to the data stores to be used by the SPBM policy." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/vmware-vmdk-driver.rst:310 msgid "" "For details about creating tags in vSphere, see the `vSphere documentation " "<http://pubs.vmware.com/vsphere-55/index.jsp#com.vmware.vsphere.vcenterhost." "doc/GUID-379F40D3-8CD6-449E-89CB-79C4E2683221.html>`__." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/vmware-vmdk-driver.rst:314 msgid "" "In vCenter, create a tag-based storage policy that uses one or more tags to " "identify a set of data stores." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/vmware-vmdk-driver.rst:319 msgid "" "For details about creating storage policies in vSphere, see the `vSphere " "documentation <http://pubs.vmware.com/vsphere-55/index.jsp#com.vmware." "vsphere.storage.doc/GUID-89091D59-D844-46B2-94C2-35A3961D23E7.html>`__." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/vmware-vmdk-driver.rst:324 msgid "Data store selection" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/vmware-vmdk-driver.rst:326 msgid "" "If storage policy is enabled, the driver initially selects all the data " "stores that match the associated storage policy." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/vmware-vmdk-driver.rst:329 msgid "" "If two or more data stores match the storage policy, the driver chooses a " "data store that is connected to the maximum number of hosts." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/vmware-vmdk-driver.rst:332 msgid "" "In case of ties, the driver chooses the data store with lowest space " "utilization, where space utilization is defined by the ``(1-freespace/" "totalspace)`` meters." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/vmware-vmdk-driver.rst:336 msgid "" "These actions reduce the number of volume migrations while attaching the " "volume to instances." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/vmware-vmdk-driver.rst:339 msgid "" "The volume must be migrated if the ESX host for the instance cannot access " "the data store that contains the volume." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/windows-iscsi-volume-driver.rst:0 msgid "Description of Windows configuration options" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/windows-iscsi-volume-driver.rst:3 msgid "Windows iSCSI volume driver" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/windows-iscsi-volume-driver.rst:5 msgid "" "Windows Server 2012 and Windows Storage Server 2012 offer an integrated " "iSCSI Target service that can be used with OpenStack Block Storage in your " "stack. Being entirely a software solution, consider it in particular for mid-" "sized networks where the costs of a SAN might be excessive." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/windows-iscsi-volume-driver.rst:10 msgid "" "The Windows Block Storage driver works with OpenStack Compute on any " "hypervisor. It includes snapshotting support and the ``boot from volume`` " "feature." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/windows-iscsi-volume-driver.rst:14 msgid "" "This driver creates volumes backed by fixed-type VHD images on Windows " "Server 2012 and dynamic-type VHDX on Windows Server 2012 R2, stored locally " "on a user-specified path. The system uses those images as iSCSI disks and " "exports them through iSCSI targets. Each volume has its own iSCSI target." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/windows-iscsi-volume-driver.rst:19 msgid "" "This driver has been tested with Windows Server 2012 and Windows Server R2 " "using the Server and Storage Server distributions." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/windows-iscsi-volume-driver.rst:22 msgid "" "Install the ``cinder-volume`` service as well as the required Python " "components directly onto the Windows node." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/windows-iscsi-volume-driver.rst:25 msgid "" "You may install and configure ``cinder-volume`` and its dependencies " "manually using the following guide or you may use the ``Cinder Volume " "Installer``, presented below." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/windows-iscsi-volume-driver.rst:30 msgid "Installing using the OpenStack cinder volume installer" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/windows-iscsi-volume-driver.rst:32 msgid "" "In case you want to avoid all the manual setup, you can use Cloudbase " "Solutions' installer. You can find it at https://www.cloudbase.it/downloads/" "CinderVolumeSetup_Beta.msi. It installs an independent Python environment, " "in order to avoid conflicts with existing applications, dynamically " "generates a ``cinder.conf`` file based on the parameters provided by you." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/windows-iscsi-volume-driver.rst:39 msgid "" "``cinder-volume`` will be configured to run as a Windows Service, which can " "be restarted using:" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/windows-iscsi-volume-driver.rst:46 msgid "" "The installer can also be used in unattended mode. More details about how to " "use the installer and its features can be found at https://www.cloudbase.it." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/windows-iscsi-volume-driver.rst:50 msgid "Windows Server configuration" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/windows-iscsi-volume-driver.rst:52 msgid "" "The required service in order to run ``cinder-volume`` on Windows is " "``wintarget``. Below is a " "configuration sample for using the Windows iSCSI Driver:" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/windows-iscsi-volume-driver.rst:108 msgid "" "The following table contains a reference to the only driver specific option " "that will be used by the Block Storage Windows driver:" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/windows-iscsi-volume-driver.rst:114 msgid "Run cinder-volume" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/windows-iscsi-volume-driver.rst:116 msgid "" "After configuring ``cinder-volume`` using the ``cinder.conf`` file, you may " "use the following commands to install and run the service (note that you " "must replace the variables with the proper paths):" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/xio-volume-driver.rst:0 msgid "Description of X-IO volume driver configuration options" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/xio-volume-driver.rst:0 msgid "Extra specs" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/xio-volume-driver.rst:3 msgid "X-IO volume driver" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/xio-volume-driver.rst:5 msgid "" "The X-IO volume driver for OpenStack Block Storage enables ISE products to " "be managed by OpenStack Block Storage nodes. This driver can be configured " "to work with iSCSI and Fibre Channel storage protocols. The X-IO volume " "driver allows the cloud operator to take advantage of ISE features like " "Quality of Service (QOS) and Continuous Adaptive Data Placement (CADP). It " "also supports creating thin volumes and specifying volume media affinity." msgstr "" # #-#-#-#-# block-storage.pot (Configuration Reference 0.9) #-#-#-#-# # #-#-#-#-# compute.pot (Configuration Reference 0.9) #-#-#-#-# # #-#-#-#-# shared-file-systems.pot (Configuration Reference 0.9) #-#-#-#-# #: ../block-storage/drivers/xio-volume-driver.rst:13 #: ../block-storage/drivers/zfssa-iscsi-driver.rst:14 #: ../block-storage/drivers/zfssa-nfs-driver.rst:10 #: ../compute/hypervisor-hyper-v.rst:196 #: ../shared-file-systems/drivers/emc-isilon-driver.rst:19 #: ../shared-file-systems/drivers/emc-vnx-driver.rst:20 #: ../shared-file-systems/drivers/glusterfs-driver.rst:31 #: ../shared-file-systems/drivers/glusterfs-native-driver.rst:56 #: ../shared-file-systems/drivers/hdfs-native-driver.rst:50 #: ../shared-file-systems/drivers/hpe-3par-share-driver.rst:67 #: ../shared-file-systems/drivers/huawei-nas-driver.rst:12 #: ../shared-file-systems/drivers/ibm-gpfs-driver.rst:38 msgid "Requirements" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/xio-volume-driver.rst:15 msgid "" "ISE FW 2.8.0 or ISE FW 3.1.0 is required for OpenStack Block Storage " "support. Be careful to use the one that matches " "the storage protocol in use:" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/xio-volume-driver.rst:43 msgid "Fibre Channel" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/xio-volume-driver.rst:64 msgid "Optional configuration parameters" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/xio-volume-driver.rst:69 msgid "Multipath" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/xio-volume-driver.rst:71 msgid "" "The X-IO ISE supports a multipath configuration, but multipath must be " "enabled on the compute node (see *ISE Storage Blade Best Practices Guide*). " "For more information, see `*www.openstack.org* <http://www.openstack.org/" ">`__." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/xio-volume-driver.rst:76 msgid "Volume types" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/xio-volume-driver.rst:78 msgid "" "OpenStack Block Storage uses volume types to help the administrator specify " "attributes for volumes. These attributes are called extra-specs. The X-IO " "volume driver support the following extra-specs." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/xio-volume-driver.rst:85 msgid "Extra-specs name" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/xio-volume-driver.rst:86 msgid "Valid values" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/xio-volume-driver.rst:88 msgid "``Feature:Raid``" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/xio-volume-driver.rst:89 msgid "1, 5" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/xio-volume-driver.rst:90 msgid "RAID level for volume." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/xio-volume-driver.rst:91 msgid "``Feature:Pool``" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/xio-volume-driver.rst:92 msgid "1 - n (n being number of pools on ISE)" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/xio-volume-driver.rst:93 msgid "Pool to create volume in." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/xio-volume-driver.rst:94 msgid "``Affinity:Type``" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/xio-volume-driver.rst:95 msgid "cadp, flash, hdd" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/xio-volume-driver.rst:96 msgid "Volume media affinity type." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/xio-volume-driver.rst:97 msgid "``Alloc:Type``" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/xio-volume-driver.rst:98 msgid "0 (thick), 1 (thin)" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/xio-volume-driver.rst:99 msgid "Allocation type for volume. Thick or thin." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/xio-volume-driver.rst:100 msgid "``QoS:minIOPS``" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/xio-volume-driver.rst:101 msgid "n (value less than maxIOPS)" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/xio-volume-driver.rst:102 msgid "Minimum IOPS setting for volume." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/xio-volume-driver.rst:103 msgid "``QoS:maxIOPS``" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/xio-volume-driver.rst:104 #: ../block-storage/drivers/xio-volume-driver.rst:107 msgid "n (value bigger than minIOPS)" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/xio-volume-driver.rst:105 msgid "Maximum IOPS setting for volume." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/xio-volume-driver.rst:106 msgid "``QoS:burstIOPS``" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/xio-volume-driver.rst:108 msgid "Burst IOPS setting for volume." msgstr "" # #-#-#-#-# block-storage.pot (Configuration Reference 0.9) #-#-#-#-# # #-#-#-#-# policy-json-file.pot (Configuration Reference 0.9) #-#-#-#-# #: ../block-storage/drivers/xio-volume-driver.rst:111 #: ../policy-json-file.rst:45 msgid "Examples" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/xio-volume-driver.rst:113 msgid "" "Create a volume type called xio1-flash for volumes that should reside on ssd " "storage:" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/xio-volume-driver.rst:121 msgid "Create a volume type called xio1 and set QoS min and max:" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/zfssa-iscsi-driver.rst:0 msgid "Description of ZFS Storage Appliance iSCSI driver configuration options" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/zfssa-iscsi-driver.rst:3 msgid "Oracle ZFS Storage Appliance iSCSI driver" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/zfssa-iscsi-driver.rst:5 msgid "" "Oracle ZFS Storage Appliances (ZFSSAs) provide advanced software to protect " "data, speed tuning and troubleshooting, and deliver high performance and " "high availability. Through the Oracle ZFSSA iSCSI Driver, OpenStack Block " "Storage can use an Oracle ZFSSA as a block storage resource. The driver " "enables you to create iSCSI volumes that an OpenStack Block Storage server " "can allocate to any virtual machine running on a compute host." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/zfssa-iscsi-driver.rst:16 msgid "" "The Oracle ZFSSA iSCSI Driver, version ``1.0.0`` and later, supports ZFSSA " "software release ``2013.1.2.0`` and later." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/zfssa-iscsi-driver.rst:24 #: ../block-storage/drivers/zfssa-nfs-driver.rst:19 msgid "Create and delete snapshots." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/zfssa-iscsi-driver.rst:26 msgid "Create volume from snapshot." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/zfssa-iscsi-driver.rst:30 msgid "Attach and detach volumes." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/zfssa-iscsi-driver.rst:32 msgid "Get volume stats." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/zfssa-iscsi-driver.rst:34 msgid "Clone volumes." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/zfssa-iscsi-driver.rst:38 msgid "Local cache of a bootable volume." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/zfssa-iscsi-driver.rst:43 msgid "Enable RESTful service on the ZFSSA Storage Appliance." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/zfssa-iscsi-driver.rst:45 msgid "Create a new user on the appliance with the following authorizations:" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/zfssa-iscsi-driver.rst:52 msgid "You can create a role with authorizations as follows:" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/zfssa-iscsi-driver.rst:66 msgid "You can create a user with a specific role as follows:" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/zfssa-iscsi-driver.rst:79 msgid "" "You can also run this `workflow <https://java.net/projects/solaris-userland/" "sources/gate/content/components/openstack/cinder/files/zfssa/cinder.akwf>`__ " "to automate the above tasks." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/zfssa-iscsi-driver.rst:83 msgid "" "Ensure that the ZFSSA iSCSI service is online. If the ZFSSA iSCSI service is " "not online, enable the service by using the BUI, CLI or REST API in the " "appliance." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/zfssa-iscsi-driver.rst:96 msgid "Define the following required properties in the ``cinder.conf`` file:" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/zfssa-iscsi-driver.rst:110 msgid "Optionally, you can define additional properties." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/zfssa-iscsi-driver.rst:112 msgid "Target interfaces can be seen as follows in the CLI:" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/zfssa-iscsi-driver.rst:125 msgid "Do not use management interfaces for ``zfssa_target_interfaces``." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/zfssa-iscsi-driver.rst:128 msgid "ZFSSA assisted volume migration" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/zfssa-iscsi-driver.rst:130 msgid "" "The ZFSSA iSCSI driver supports storage assisted volume migration starting " "in the Liberty release. This feature uses remote replication feature on the " "ZFSSA. Volumes can be migrated between two backends configured not only to " "the same ZFSSA but also between two separate ZFSSAs altogether." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/zfssa-iscsi-driver.rst:136 msgid "" "The following conditions must be met in order to use ZFSSA assisted volume " "migration:" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/zfssa-iscsi-driver.rst:139 msgid "Both the source and target backends are configured to ZFSSAs." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/zfssa-iscsi-driver.rst:141 msgid "" "Remote replication service on the source and target appliance is enabled." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/zfssa-iscsi-driver.rst:143 msgid "" "The ZFSSA to which the target backend is configured should be configured as " "a target in the remote replication service of the ZFSSA configured to the " "source backend. The remote replication target needs to be configured even " "when the source and the destination for volume migration are the same ZFSSA. " "Define ``zfssa_replication_ip`` in the ``cinder.conf`` file of the source " "backend as the IP address used to register the target ZFSSA in the remote " "replication service of the source ZFSSA." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/zfssa-iscsi-driver.rst:151 msgid "" "The name of the iSCSI target group(``zfssa_target_group``) on the source and " "the destination ZFSSA is the same." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/zfssa-iscsi-driver.rst:154 msgid "The volume is not attached and is in available state." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/zfssa-iscsi-driver.rst:156 msgid "" "If any of the above conditions are not met, the driver will proceed with " "generic volume migration." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/zfssa-iscsi-driver.rst:159 msgid "" "The ZFSSA user on the source and target appliances will need to have " "additional role authorizations for assisted volume migration to work. In " "scope nas, set ``allow_rrtarget`` and ``allow_rrsource`` to ``true``." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/zfssa-iscsi-driver.rst:170 #: ../block-storage/drivers/zfssa-nfs-driver.rst:241 msgid "ZFSSA local cache" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/zfssa-iscsi-driver.rst:172 #: ../block-storage/drivers/zfssa-nfs-driver.rst:243 msgid "" "The local cache feature enables ZFSSA drivers to serve the usage of bootable " "volumes significantly better. With the feature, the first bootable volume " "created from an image is cached, so that subsequent volumes can be created " "directly from the cache, instead of having image data transferred over the " "network multiple times." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/zfssa-iscsi-driver.rst:178 #: ../block-storage/drivers/zfssa-nfs-driver.rst:249 msgid "" "The following conditions must be met in order to use ZFSSA local cache " "feature:" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/zfssa-iscsi-driver.rst:180 #: ../block-storage/drivers/zfssa-nfs-driver.rst:252 msgid "A storage pool needs to be configured." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/zfssa-iscsi-driver.rst:182 msgid "REST and iSCSI services need to be turned on." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/zfssa-iscsi-driver.rst:184 msgid "" "On an OpenStack controller, ``cinder.conf`` needs to contain necessary " "properties used to configure and set up the ZFSSA iSCSI driver, including " "the following new properties:" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/zfssa-iscsi-driver.rst:188 msgid "" "``zfssa_enable_local_cache``: (True/False) To enable/disable the feature." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/zfssa-iscsi-driver.rst:190 msgid "" "``zfssa_cache_project``: The ZFSSA project name where cache volumes are " "stored." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/zfssa-iscsi-driver.rst:193 msgid "" "Every cache volume has two additional properties stored as ZFSSA custom " "schema. It is important that the schema are not altered outside of Block " "Storage when the driver is in use:" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/zfssa-iscsi-driver.rst:197 msgid "``image_id``: stores the image id as in Image service." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/zfssa-iscsi-driver.rst:199 msgid "" "``updated_at``: stores the most current timestamp when the image is updated " "in Image service." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/zfssa-iscsi-driver.rst:203 msgid "Supported extra specs" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/zfssa-iscsi-driver.rst:205 msgid "" "Extra specs provide the OpenStack storage admin the flexibility to create " "volumes with different characteristics from the ones specified in the " "``cinder.conf`` file. The admin will specify the volume properties as keys " "at volume type creation. When a user requests a volume of this volume type, " "the volume will be created with the properties specified as extra specs." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/zfssa-iscsi-driver.rst:211 msgid "The following extra specs scoped keys are supported by the driver:" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/zfssa-iscsi-driver.rst:213 msgid "``zfssa:volblocksize``" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/zfssa-iscsi-driver.rst:215 msgid "``zfssa:sparse``" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/zfssa-iscsi-driver.rst:217 msgid "``zfssa:compression``" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/zfssa-iscsi-driver.rst:219 msgid "``zfssa:logbias``" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/zfssa-iscsi-driver.rst:221 msgid "" "Volume types can be created using the :command:`cinder type-create` command. " "Extra spec keys can be added using :command:`cinder type-key` command." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/zfssa-iscsi-driver.rst:227 msgid "The Oracle ZFSSA iSCSI Driver supports these options:" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/zfssa-nfs-driver.rst:0 msgid "Description of ZFS Storage Appliance NFS driver configuration options" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/zfssa-nfs-driver.rst:3 msgid "Oracle ZFS Storage Appliance NFS driver" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/zfssa-nfs-driver.rst:5 msgid "" "The Oracle ZFS Storage Appliance (ZFSSA) NFS driver enables the ZFSSA to be " "used seamlessly as a block storage resource. " "REST service needs to stay online for this driver to function." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/drivers/zfssa-nfs-driver.rst:54 msgid "" "Create a new storage pool on the appliance if you do not want to use an " "existing one. The configuration of Fibre " "Channel Zone Manager and various zone drivers are described in this section." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/fc-zoning.rst:11 msgid "Configure Block Storage to use Fibre Channel Zone Manager" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/fc-zoning.rst:13 msgid "" "If Block Storage is configured to use a Fibre Channel volume driver that " "supports Zone Manager, update ``cinder.conf`` to add the following " "configuration options to enable Fibre Channel Zone Manager." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/fc-zoning.rst:21 msgid "" "To use different Fibre Channel Zone Drivers, use the parameters described in " "this section." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/fc-zoning.rst:26 msgid "" "When multi backend configuration is used, provide the ``zoning_mode`` " "configuration option as part of the volume driver configuration where " "``volume_driver`` option is specified." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/fc-zoning.rst:32 msgid "" "Default value of ``zoning_mode`` is ``None`` and this needs to be changed to " "``fabric`` to allow fabric zoning." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/fc-zoning.rst:37 msgid "" "``zoning_policy`` can be configured as ``initiator-target`` or ``initiator``" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/fc-zoning.rst:41 msgid "Brocade Fibre Channel Zone Driver" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/fc-zoning.rst:43 msgid "" "Brocade Fibre Channel Zone Driver performs zoning operations through SSH. " "Configure Brocade Zone Driver and lookup service by specifying the following " "parameters:" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/fc-zoning.rst:49 msgid "" "Configure SAN fabric parameters in the form of fabric groups as described in " "the example below:" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/fc-zoning.rst:56 msgid "" "Define a fabric group for each fabric using the fabric names used in " "``fc_fabric_names`` configuration option as group name." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/fc-zoning.rst:62 msgid "" "Brocade Fibre Channel Zone Driver requires firmware version FOS v6.4 or " "higher." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/fc-zoning.rst:65 msgid "" "As a best practice for zone management, use a user account with " "``zoneadmin`` role. Users with ``admin`` role (including the default " "``admin`` user account) are limited to a maximum of two concurrent SSH " "sessions." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/fc-zoning.rst:70 msgid "" "For information about how to manage Brocade Fibre Channel switches, see the " "Brocade Fabric OS user documentation." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/logs.rst:0 msgid "**Log files used by Block Storage services**" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/logs.rst:3 msgid "Log files used by Block Storage" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/logs.rst:5 msgid "" "The corresponding log file of each Block Storage service is stored in the ``/" "var/log/cinder/`` directory of the host on which each service runs." msgstr "" # #-#-#-#-# block-storage.pot (Configuration Reference 0.9) #-#-#-#-# # #-#-#-#-# shared-file-systems.pot (Configuration Reference 0.9) #-#-#-#-# #: ../block-storage/logs.rst:15 ../shared-file-systems/log-files.rst:15 msgid "Service/interface (for Ubuntu and Debian)" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/logs.rst:16 msgid "api.log" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/logs.rst:17 msgid "openstack-cinder-api" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/logs.rst:18 msgid "cinder-api" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/logs.rst:19 msgid "cinder-manage.log" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/logs.rst:20 ../block-storage/logs.rst:21 msgid "cinder-manage" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/logs.rst:22 msgid "scheduler.log" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/logs.rst:23 msgid "openstack-cinder-scheduler" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/logs.rst:24 msgid "cinder-scheduler" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/logs.rst:25 msgid "volume.log" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/logs.rst:26 msgid "openstack-cinder-volume" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/logs.rst:27 msgid "cinder-volume" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/nested-quota.rst:3 msgid "Nested quotas" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/nested-quota.rst:5 msgid "" "Nested quota is a change in how OpenStack services (such as Block Storage " "and Compute) handle their quota resources by being hierarchy-aware. The main " "reason for this change is to fully appreciate the hierarchical multitenancy " "concept, which was introduced in keystone in the Kilo release." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/nested-quota.rst:10 msgid "" "Once you have a project hierarchy created in keystone, nested quotas let you " "define how much of a project's quota you want to give to its subprojects. In " "that way, hierarchical projects can have hierarchical quotas (also known as " "nested quotas)." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/nested-quota.rst:15 msgid "" "Projects and subprojects have similar behaviours, but they differ from each " "other when it comes to default quota values. The default quota value for " "resources in a subproject is 0, so that when a subproject is created it will " "not consume all of its parent's quota." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/nested-quota.rst:20 msgid "" "In order to keep track of how much of each quota was allocated to a " "subproject, a column ``allocated`` was added to the quotas table. This " "column is updated after every delete and update quota operation." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/nested-quota.rst:24 msgid "This example shows you how to use nested quotas." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/nested-quota.rst:28 msgid "" "Assume that you have created a project hierarchy in keystone, such as " "follows:" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/nested-quota.rst:43 msgid "Getting default quotas" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/nested-quota.rst:45 msgid "Get the quota for root projects." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/nested-quota.rst:47 msgid "Use the cinder :command:`quota-show` command and specify:" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/nested-quota.rst:49 msgid "" "The ``TENANT_ID`` of the relevant project. In this case, the id of project A." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/nested-quota.rst:71 msgid "" "This command returns the default values for resources. This is because the " "quotas for this project were not explicitly set." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/nested-quota.rst:74 msgid "Get the quota for subprojects." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/nested-quota.rst:76 msgid "In this case, use the same :command:`quota-show` command and specify:" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/nested-quota.rst:78 msgid "" "The ``TENANT_ID`` of the relevant project. In this case the id of project B, " "which is a child of A." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/nested-quota.rst:100 msgid "" "In this case, 0 was the value returned as the quota for all the resources. " "This is because project B is a subproject of A, thus, the default quota " "value is 0, so that it will not consume all the quota of its parent project." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/nested-quota.rst:106 msgid "Setting the quotas for subprojects" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/nested-quota.rst:108 msgid "" "Now that the projects were created, assume that the admin of project B wants " "to use it. First of all, you need to set the quota limit of the project, " "because as a subproject it does not have quotas allocated by default." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/nested-quota.rst:112 msgid "" "In this example, when all of the parent project is allocated to its " "subprojects the user will not be able to create more resources in the parent " "project." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/nested-quota.rst:116 msgid "Update the quota of B." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/nested-quota.rst:118 msgid "Use the :command:`quota-update` command and specify:" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/nested-quota.rst:120 msgid "" "The ``TENANT_ID`` of the relevant project. In this case the id of project B." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/nested-quota.rst:123 msgid "" "The ``--volumes`` option, followed by the number to which you wish to " "increase the volumes quota." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/nested-quota.rst:145 msgid "The volumes resource quota is updated." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/nested-quota.rst:147 msgid "Try to create a volume in project A." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/nested-quota.rst:149 msgid "Use the :command:`create` command and specify:" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/nested-quota.rst:151 msgid "The ``SIZE`` of the volume that will be created;" msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/nested-quota.rst:153 msgid "The ``NAME`` of the volume." msgstr "" #: ../block-storage/nested-quota.rst:162 msgid "" "As the entirety of project A's volumes quota has been assigned to project B, " "it is treated as if all of the quota has been used.
