You can use OpenStack Compute to host " "and manage cloud computing systems. This section describes the OpenStack " "Compute configuration options." msgstr "" #: ../compute.rst:32 msgid "" "To configure your Compute installation, you must define configuration " "options in these files:" msgstr "" #: ../compute.rst:35 msgid "" "``nova.conf``. Contains most of the Compute configuration options. Resides " "in the ``/etc/nova`` directory." msgstr "" #: ../compute.rst:37 msgid "" "``api-paste.ini``. Defines Compute limits. Resides in the ``/etc/nova`` " "directory." msgstr "" #: ../compute.rst:39 msgid "" "Related Image service and Identity service management configuration files." msgstr "" #: ../compute/api-paste.ini.rst:5 msgid "" "The Compute service stores its API configuration settings in the ``api-paste." "ini`` file." msgstr "" #: ../compute/api.rst:0 msgid "Default API rate limits" msgstr "" #: ../compute/api.rst:3 msgid "Configure the Compute API" msgstr "" #: ../compute/api.rst:5 msgid "" "The Compute API, run by the ``nova-api`` daemon, is the component of " "OpenStack Compute that receives and responds to user requests, whether they " "be direct API calls, or via the CLI tools or dashboard." msgstr "" #: ../compute/api.rst:10 msgid "Configure Compute API password handling" msgstr "" #: ../compute/api.rst:12 msgid "" "The OpenStack Compute API enables users to specify an administrative " "password when they create or rebuild a server instance. If the user does not " "specify a password, a random password is generated and returned in the API " "response." msgstr "" #: ../compute/api.rst:17 msgid "" "In practice, how the admin password is handled depends on the hypervisor in " "use and might require additional configuration of the instance. For example, " "you might have to install an agent to handle the password setting. If the " "hypervisor and instance configuration do not support setting a password at " "server create time, the password that is returned by the create API call is " "misleading because it was ignored." msgstr "" #: ../compute/api.rst:24 msgid "" "To prevent this confusion, use the ``enable_instance_password`` " "configuration option to disable the return of the admin password for " "installations that do not support setting instance passwords." msgstr "" #: ../compute/api.rst:29 msgid "Configure Compute API rate limiting" msgstr "" #: ../compute/api.rst:31 msgid "" "OpenStack Compute supports API rate limiting for the OpenStack API. The rate " "limiting allows an administrator to configure limits on the type and number " "of API calls that can be made in a specific time interval." msgstr "" #: ../compute/api.rst:35 msgid "" "When API rate limits are exceeded, HTTP requests return an error with a " "status code of ``403 Forbidden``." msgstr "" #: ../compute/api.rst:38 msgid "Rate limiting is not available for the EC2 API." msgstr "" #: ../compute/api.rst:41 msgid "Define limits" msgstr "" #: ../compute/api.rst:43 msgid "To define limits, set these values:" msgstr "" #: ../compute/api.rst:45 msgid "" "The **HTTP method** used in the API call, typically one of GET, PUT, POST, " "or DELETE." msgstr "" #: ../compute/api.rst:47 msgid "" "A **human readable URI** that is used as a friendly description of where the " "limit is applied." msgstr "" #: ../compute/api.rst:49 msgid "" "A **regular expression**. The limit is applied to all URIs that match the " "regular expression and HTTP method." msgstr "" #: ../compute/api.rst:51 msgid "" "A **limit value** that specifies the maximum count of units before the limit " "takes effect." msgstr "" #: ../compute/api.rst:53 msgid "" "An **interval** that specifies time frame to which the limit is applied. The " "interval can be SECOND, MINUTE, HOUR, or DAY." msgstr "" #: ../compute/api.rst:56 msgid "" "Rate limits are applied in relative order to the HTTP method, going from " "least to most specific." msgstr "" #: ../compute/api.rst:60 msgid "Default limits" msgstr "" #: ../compute/api.rst:62 msgid "" "Normally, you install OpenStack Compute with the following limits enabled:" msgstr "" #: ../compute/api.rst:67 ../compute/api.rst:121 msgid "HTTP method" msgstr "" #: ../compute/api.rst:68 msgid "API URI" msgstr "" #: ../compute/api.rst:69 msgid "API regular expression" msgstr "" #: ../compute/api.rst:70 msgid "Limit" msgstr "" #: ../compute/api.rst:71 ../compute/api.rst:75 msgid "POST" msgstr "" #: ../compute/api.rst:72 ../compute/api.rst:80 ../compute/api.rst:88 msgid "any URI (\*)" msgstr "" #: ../compute/api.rst:73 ../compute/api.rst:81 ../compute/api.rst:89 msgid ".\*" msgstr "" #: ../compute/api.rst:74 ../compute/api.rst:78 ../compute/api.rst:82 #: ../compute/api.rst:86 ../compute/api.rst:90 msgid "120 per minute" msgstr "" #: ../compute/api.rst:76 msgid "/servers" msgstr "" #: ../compute/api.rst:77 msgid "^/servers" msgstr "" #: ../compute/api.rst:79 msgid "PUT" msgstr "" #: ../compute/api.rst:83 ../compute/api.rst:91 msgid "GET" msgstr "" #: ../compute/api.rst:84 msgid "\*changes-since\*" msgstr "" #: ../compute/api.rst:85 msgid ".\*changes-since.\*" msgstr "" #: ../compute/api.rst:87 msgid "DELETE" msgstr "" #: ../compute/api.rst:92 msgid "\*/os-fping" msgstr "" #: ../compute/api.rst:93 msgid "^/os-fping" msgstr "" #: ../compute/api.rst:94 msgid "12 per minute" msgstr "" #: ../compute/api.rst:97 msgid "Configure and change limits" msgstr "" #: ../compute/api.rst:99 msgid "" "As part of the WSGI pipeline, the ``etc/nova/api-paste.ini`` file defines " "the actual limits." msgstr "" #: ../compute/api.rst:102 msgid "" "To enable limits, include the ``ratelimit`` filter in the API pipeline " "specification. If the ``ratelimit`` filter is removed from the pipeline, " "limiting is disabled. You must also define the rate limit filter. The lines " "appear as follows:" msgstr "" #: ../compute/api.rst:118 msgid "" "To modify the limits, add a ``limits`` specification to the ``[filter:" "ratelimit]`` section of the file. Specify the limits in this order:" msgstr "" #: ../compute/api.rst:122 msgid "friendly URI" msgstr "" #: ../compute/api.rst:123 msgid "regex" msgstr "" #: ../compute/api.rst:124 msgid "limit" msgstr "" #: ../compute/api.rst:125 msgid "interval" msgstr "" #: ../compute/api.rst:127 msgid "The following example shows the default rate-limiting values:" msgstr "" #: ../compute/api.rst:136 ../compute/hypervisor-vmware.rst:969 #: ../compute/scheduler.rst:1164 msgid "Configuration reference" msgstr "" #: ../compute/api.rst:138 msgid "" "The Compute API configuration options are documented in the table :ref:`nova-" "api`." msgstr "" #: ../compute/authentication-authorization.rst:3 msgid "Configure authentication and authorization" msgstr "" #: ../compute/authentication-authorization.rst:5 msgid "" "There are different methods of authentication for the OpenStack Compute " "project, including no authentication. The preferred system is the OpenStack " "Identity service, code-named keystone." msgstr "" #: ../compute/authentication-authorization.rst:10 msgid "" "To customize authorization settings for Compute, use the configuration " "options documented in the table :ref:`nova-authentication`." msgstr "" #: ../compute/authentication-authorization.rst:13 msgid "" "To customize certificate authority settings for Compute, use the " "configuration options documented in the table :ref:`nova-ca`." msgstr "" #: ../compute/authentication-authorization.rst:16 msgid "" "To customize Compute and the Identity service to use LDAP as a backend, " "refer to the configuration options documented in the table :ref:`nova-ldap`" ""." msgstr "" #: ../compute/cells.rst:3 msgid "Cells" msgstr "" #: ../compute/cells.rst:5 msgid "" "``Cells`` functionality enables you to scale an OpenStack Compute cloud in a " "more distributed fashion without having to use complicated technologies like " "database and message queue clustering. It supports very large deployments." msgstr "" #: ../compute/cells.rst:10 msgid "" "When this functionality is enabled, the hosts in an OpenStack Compute cloud " "are partitioned into groups called cells. Cells are configured as a tree. " "The top-level cell should have a host that runs a ``nova-api`` service, but " "no ``nova-compute`` services. Each child cell should run all of the typical " "``nova-*`` services in a regular Compute cloud except for ``nova-api``. You " "can think of cells as a normal Compute deployment in that each cell has its " "own database server and message queue broker." msgstr "" #: ../compute/cells.rst:19 msgid "" "The ``nova-cells`` service handles communication between cells and selects " "cells for new instances. This service is required for every cell. " "Communication between cells is pluggable, and currently the only option is " "communication through RPC." msgstr "" #: ../compute/cells.rst:24 msgid "" "Cells scheduling is separate from host scheduling. ``nova-cells`` first " "picks a cell. Once a cell is selected and the new build request reaches its " "``nova-cells`` service, it is sent over to the host scheduler in that cell " "and the build proceeds as it would have without cells." msgstr "" #: ../compute/cells.rst:32 msgid "Cell functionality is currently considered experimental." msgstr "" #: ../compute/cells.rst:35 msgid "Cell configuration options" msgstr "" #: ../compute/cells.rst:37 msgid "" "Cells are disabled by default. All cell-related configuration options appear " "in the ``[cells]`` section in ``nova.conf``. The following cell-related " "options are currently supported:" msgstr "" #: ../compute/cells.rst:42 msgid "Set to ``True`` to turn on cell functionality. Default is ``false``." msgstr "" #: ../compute/cells.rst:42 msgid "enable" msgstr "" #: ../compute/cells.rst:45 msgid "Name of the current cell. Must be unique for each cell." msgstr "" #: ../compute/cells.rst:45 msgid "name" msgstr "" #: ../compute/cells.rst:48 msgid "" "List of arbitrary ``key=value`` pairs defining capabilities of the current " "cell. Values include ``hypervisor=xenserver;kvm,os=linux;windows``." msgstr "" #: ../compute/cells.rst:49 msgid "capabilities" msgstr "" #: ../compute/cells.rst:52 msgid "How long in seconds to wait for replies from calls between cells." msgstr "" #: ../compute/cells.rst:52 msgid "call_timeout" msgstr "" #: ../compute/cells.rst:55 msgid "" "Filter classes that the cells scheduler should use. By default, uses ``nova." "cells.filters.all_filters`` to map to all cells filters included with " "Compute." msgstr "" #: ../compute/cells.rst:57 ../compute/cells.rst:204 msgid "scheduler_filter_classes" msgstr "" #: ../compute/cells.rst:60 msgid "" "Weight classes that the scheduler for cells uses. By default, uses ``nova." "cells.weights.all_weighers`` to map to all cells weight algorithms included " "with Compute." msgstr "" #: ../compute/cells.rst:62 ../compute/cells.rst:228 msgid "scheduler_weight_classes" msgstr "" #: ../compute/cells.rst:65 msgid "" "Multiplier used to weight RAM. Negative numbers indicate that Compute should " "stack VMs on one host instead of spreading out new VMs to more hosts in the " "cell. The default value is 10.0." msgstr "" #: ../compute/cells.rst:67 msgid "ram_weight_multiplier" msgstr "" #: ../compute/cells.rst:70 msgid "Configure the API (top-level) cell" msgstr "" #: ../compute/cells.rst:72 msgid "" "The cell type must be changed in the API cell so that requests can be " "proxied through nova-cells down to the correct cell properly. Edit the " "``nova.conf`` file in the API cell, and specify ``api`` in the ``cell_type`` " "key:" msgstr "" #: ../compute/cells.rst:87 msgid "Configure the child cells" msgstr "" #: ../compute/cells.rst:89 msgid "" "Edit the ``nova.conf`` file in the child cells, and specify ``compute`` in " "the ``cell_type`` key:" msgstr "" #: ../compute/cells.rst:102 msgid "Configure the database in each cell" msgstr "" #: ../compute/cells.rst:104 msgid "" "Before bringing the services online, the database in each cell needs to be " "configured with information about related cells. In particular, the API cell " "needs to know about its immediate children, and the child cells must know " "about their immediate agents. The information needed is the ``RabbitMQ`` " "server credentials for the particular cell." msgstr "" #: ../compute/cells.rst:111 msgid "" "Use the :command:`nova-manage cell create` command to add this information " "to the database in each cell:" msgstr "" #: ../compute/cells.rst:147 msgid "" "As an example, assume an API cell named ``api`` and a child cell named " "``cell1``." msgstr "" #: ../compute/cells.rst:150 msgid "" "Within the ``api`` cell, specify the following ``RabbitMQ`` server " "information:" msgstr "" #: ../compute/cells.rst:161 msgid "" "Within the ``cell1`` child cell, specify the following ``RabbitMQ`` server " "information:" msgstr "" #: ../compute/cells.rst:172 msgid "You can run this in the API cell as root:" msgstr "" #: ../compute/cells.rst:180 msgid "Repeat the previous steps for all child cells." msgstr "" #: ../compute/cells.rst:182 msgid "In the child cell, run the following, as root:" msgstr "" #: ../compute/cells.rst:190 msgid "" "To customize the Compute cells, use the configuration option settings " "documented in the table :ref:`nova-cells`." msgstr "" #: ../compute/cells.rst:194 msgid "Cell scheduling configuration" msgstr "" #: ../compute/cells.rst:196 msgid "" "To determine the best cell to use to launch a new instance, Compute uses a " "set of filters and weights defined in the ``/etc/nova/nova.conf`` file. The " "following options are available to prioritize cells for scheduling:" msgstr "" #: ../compute/cells.rst:202 msgid "" "List of filter classes. By default ``nova.cells.filters.all_filters`` is " "specified, which maps to all cells filters included with Compute (see the " "section called :ref:`Filters <compute-scheduler-filters>`)." msgstr "" #: ../compute/cells.rst:207 msgid "" "List of weight classes. By default ``nova.cells.weights.all_weighers`` is " "specified, which maps to all cell weight algorithms included with Compute. " "The following modules are available:" msgstr "" #: ../compute/cells.rst:212 msgid "" "``mute_child``. Downgrades the likelihood of child cells being chosen for " "scheduling requests, which haven't sent capacity or capability updates in a " "while. Options include ``mute_weight_multiplier`` (multiplier for mute " "children; value should be negative)." msgstr "" #: ../compute/cells.rst:216 msgid "" "``ram_by_instance_type``. Select cells with the most RAM capacity for the " "instance type being requested. Because higher weights win, Compute returns " "the number of available units for the instance type requested. The " "``ram_weight_multiplier`` option defaults to 10.0 that adds to the weight by " "a factor of 10. Use a negative number to stack VMs on one host instead of " "spreading out new VMs to more hosts in the cell." msgstr "" #: ../compute/cells.rst:223 msgid "" "``weight_offset``. Allows modifying the database to weight a particular " "cell. You can use this when you want to disable a cell (for example, '0'), " "or to set a default cell by making its ``weight_offset`` very high (for " "example, '999999999999999'). The highest weight will be the first cell to be " "scheduled for launching an instance." msgstr "" #: ../compute/cells.rst:230 msgid "" "Additionally, the following options are available for the cell scheduler:" msgstr "" #: ../compute/cells.rst:233 msgid "" "Specifies how many times the scheduler tries to launch a new instance when " "no cells are available (default=10)." msgstr "" #: ../compute/cells.rst:234 msgid "scheduler_retries" msgstr "" #: ../compute/cells.rst:237 msgid "Specifies the delay (in seconds) between retries (default=2)." msgstr "" #: ../compute/cells.rst:237 msgid "scheduler_retry_delay" msgstr "" #: ../compute/cells.rst:239 msgid "" "As an admin user, you can also add a filter that directs builds to a " "particular cell. The ``policy.json`` file must have a line with ``" ""cells_scheduler_filter:TargetCellFilter" : "is_admin:True"`` to let an " "admin user specify a scheduler hint to direct a build to a particular cell." msgstr "" #: ../compute/cells.rst:246 msgid "Optional cell configuration" msgstr "" #: ../compute/cells.rst:248 msgid "" "Cells store all inter-cell communication data, including user names and " "passwords, in the database. Because the cells data is not updated very " "frequently, use the ``[cells]cells_config`` option to specify a JSON file to " "store cells data. With this configuration, the database is no longer " "consulted when reloading the cells data. The file must have columns present " "in the Cell model (excluding common database fields and the ``id`` column). " "You must specify the queue connection information through a " "``transport_url`` field, instead of ``username``, ``password``, and so on. " "The ``transport_url`` has the following form:" msgstr "" #: ../compute/cells.rst:263 msgid "" "The scheme can be either ``qpid`` or ``rabbit``, as shown previously. The " "following sample shows this optional configuration:" msgstr "" #: ../compute/conductor.rst:3 msgid "Conductor" msgstr "" #: ../compute/conductor.rst:5 msgid "" "The ``nova-conductor`` service enables OpenStack to function without compute " "nodes accessing the database. Conceptually, it implements a new layer on top " "of ``nova-compute``. It should not be deployed on compute nodes, or else the " "security benefits of removing database access from ``nova-compute`` are " "negated. Just like other nova services such as ``nova-api`` or ``nova-" "scheduler``, it can be scaled horizontally. You can run multiple instances " "of ``nova-conductor`` on different machines as needed for scaling purposes." msgstr "" #: ../compute/conductor.rst:15 msgid "" "The methods exposed by ``nova-conductor`` are relatively simple methods used " "by ``nova-compute`` to offload its database operations. Places where ``nova-" "compute`` previously performed database access are now talking to ``nova-" "conductor``. However, we have plans in the medium to long term to move more " "and more of what is currently in ``nova-compute`` up to the ``nova-" "conductor`` layer. The Compute service will start to look like a less " "intelligent slave service to ``nova-conductor``. The conductor service will " "implement long running complex operations, ensuring forward progress and " "graceful error handling. This will be especially beneficial for operations " "that cross multiple compute nodes, such as migrations or resizes." msgstr "" #: ../compute/conductor.rst:28 msgid "" "To customize the ``Conductor``, use the configuration option settings " "documented in the table :ref:`nova-conductor`." msgstr "" #: ../compute/config-options.rst:0 msgid "Description of API v2.1 configuration options" msgstr "" #: ../compute/config-options.rst:0 msgid "Description of Barbican configuration options" msgstr "" # The database name is ``nova``. The ``nova-conductor`` service is " "the only service that writes to the database. The other Compute services " "access the database through the ``nova-conductor`` service." msgstr "" #: ../compute/database-connections.rst:10 msgid "" "To ensure that the database schema is current, run the following command:" msgstr "" #: ../compute/database-connections.rst:16 msgid "" "If ``nova-conductor`` is not used, entries to the database are mostly " "written by the ``nova-scheduler`` service, although all services must be " "able to update entries in the database." msgstr "" #: ../compute/database-connections.rst:20 msgid "" "In either case, use the configuration option settings documented in the " "table :ref:`nova-database` to configure the connection string for the nova " "database." msgstr "" #: ../compute/ec2-api.rst:3 msgid "Configure the EC2 API" msgstr "" #: ../compute/ec2-api.rst:5 msgid "" "You can set options in the ``nova.conf`` configuration file to control which " "network address and port the EC2 API listens on, the formatting of some API " "responses, and authentication related options." msgstr "" #: ../compute/ec2-api.rst:9 msgid "" "To customize these options for OpenStack EC2 API, use the configuration " "option settings documented in the table :ref:`nova-ec2`." msgstr "" #: ../compute/fibre-channel.rst:3 msgid "Fibre Channel support in Compute" msgstr "" #: ../compute/fibre-channel.rst:5 msgid "" "Fibre Channel support in OpenStack Compute is remote block storage attached " "to compute nodes for VMs." msgstr "" #: ../compute/fibre-channel.rst:10 msgid "Fibre Channel supported only the KVM hypervisor." msgstr "" #: ../compute/fibre-channel.rst:12 msgid "" "Compute and Block Storage support Fibre Channel automatic zoning on Brocade " "and Cisco switches. On other hardware Fibre Channel arrays must be pre-zoned " "or directly attached to the KVM hosts." msgstr "" #: ../compute/fibre-channel.rst:17 msgid "KVM host requirements" msgstr "" #: ../compute/fibre-channel.rst:19 msgid "You must install these packages on the KVM host:" msgstr "" #: ../compute/fibre-channel.rst:21 msgid "``sysfsutils`` - Nova uses the ``systool`` application in this package." msgstr "" #: ../compute/fibre-channel.rst:22 msgid "" "``sg3-utils`` or ``sg3_utils`` - Nova uses the ``sg_scan`` and ``sginfo`` " "applications." msgstr "" #: ../compute/fibre-channel.rst:25 msgid "" "Installing the ``multipath-tools`` or ``device-mapper-multipath`` package is " "optional." msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-basics.rst:3 msgid "Hypervisor configuration basics" msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-basics.rst:5 msgid "" "The node where the ``nova-compute`` service is installed and operates on the " "same node that runs all of the virtual machines. This is referred to as the " "compute node in this guide." msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-basics.rst:9 msgid "" "By default, the selected hypervisor is KVM. To change to another hypervisor, " "change the ``virt_type`` option in the ``[libvirt]`` section of ``nova." "conf`` and restart the ``nova-compute`` service." msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-basics.rst:13 msgid "" "Here are the general ``nova.conf`` options that are used to configure the " "compute node's hypervisor: :ref:`nova-hypervisor`" msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-basics.rst:16 msgid "" "Specific options for particular hypervisors can be found in the following " "sections." msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-hyper-v.rst:3 msgid "Hyper-V virtualization platform" msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-hyper-v.rst:5 msgid "" "It is possible to use Hyper-V as a compute node within an OpenStack " "Deployment. The ``nova-compute`` service runs as ``openstack-compute``, a 32-" "bit service directly upon the Windows platform with the Hyper-V role " "enabled. The necessary Python components as well as the ``nova-compute`` " "service are installed directly onto the Windows platform. Windows Clustering " "Services are not needed for functionality within the OpenStack " "infrastructure. The use of the Windows Server 2012 platform is recommend for " "the best experience and is the platform for active development. The " "following Windows platforms have been tested as compute nodes:" msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-hyper-v.rst:17 msgid "" "Both Server and Server Core with the Hyper-V role enabled (Shared Nothing " "Live migration is not supported using 2008 R2)" msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-hyper-v.rst:18 msgid "Windows Server 2008 R2" msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-hyper-v.rst:21 msgid "Server and Core (with the Hyper-V role enabled), and Hyper-V Server" msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-hyper-v.rst:21 msgid "Windows Server 2012 and Windows Server 2012 R2" msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-hyper-v.rst:24 msgid "Hyper-V configuration" msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-hyper-v.rst:26 msgid "" "The only OpenStack services required on a Hyper-V node are ``nova-compute`` " "and ``neutron-hyperv-agent``. Regarding the resources needed for this host " "you have to consider that Hyper-V will require 16 GB - 20 GB of disk space " "for the OS itself, including updates. Two NICs are required, one connected " "to the management network and one to the guest data network." msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-hyper-v.rst:32 msgid "" "The following sections discuss how to prepare the Windows Hyper-V node for " "operation as an OpenStack compute node. Unless stated otherwise, any " "configuration information should work for the Windows 2008 R2, 2012 and 2012 " "R2 platforms." msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-hyper-v.rst:38 msgid "Local storage considerations" msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-hyper-v.rst:40 msgid "" "The Hyper-V compute node needs to have ample storage for storing the virtual " "machine images running on the compute nodes. You may use a single volume for " "all, or partition it into an OS volume and VM volume." msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-hyper-v.rst:47 msgid "Configure NTP" msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-hyper-v.rst:49 msgid "" "Network time services must be configured to ensure proper operation of the " "OpenStack nodes. To set network time on your Windows host you must run the " "following commands:" msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-hyper-v.rst:59 msgid "" "Keep in mind that the node will have to be time synchronized with the other " "nodes of your OpenStack environment, so it is important to use the same NTP " "server. Note that in case of an Active Directory environment, you may do " "this only for the AD Domain Controller." msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-hyper-v.rst:65 msgid "Configure Hyper-V virtual switching" msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-hyper-v.rst:67 msgid "" "Information regarding the Hyper-V virtual Switch can be located here: http://" "technet.microsoft.com/en-us/library/hh831823.aspx" msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-hyper-v.rst:70 msgid "" "To quickly enable an interface to be used as a Virtual Interface the " "following not already available on the target host." msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-hyper-v.rst:109 msgid "" "The source host ensures that live migration is enabled and properly " "configured in Hyper-V." migrations. It is used " "in ``nova/compute/manager.py``." msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-hyper-v.rst:125 msgid "" "This flag is needed to support live migration to hosts with different CPU " "features. ../compute/hypervisor-kvm.rst:218 msgid "For PowerNV platform, run the following command:" msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-kvm.rst:228 msgid "Configure Compute backing storage" msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-kvm.rst:230 msgid "" "Backing Storage is the storage used to provide the expanded operating system " "image, and any ephemeral storage. Inside the virtual machine, this is " "normally presented as two virtual hard disks (for example, ``/dev/vda`` and " "``/dev/vdb`` respectively). However, inside OpenStack, this can be derived " "from one of three methods: ``lvm``, ``qcow`` or ``raw``, chosen using the " "``images_type`` option in ``nova.conf`` on the compute node." msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-kvm.rst:237 msgid "" "QCOW is the default backing store. It uses a copy-on-write philosophy to " "delay allocation of storage until it is actually needed. This means that the " "space required for the backing of an image can be significantly less on the " "real disk than what seems available in the virtual machine operating system." msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-kvm.rst:242 msgid "" "RAW creates files without any sort of file formatting, effectively creating " "files with the plain binary one would normally see on a real disk. This can " "increase performance, but means that the entire size of the virtual disk is " "reserved on the physical disk." msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-kvm.rst:247 msgid "" "Local `LVM volumes <http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/" "Logical_Volume_Manager_(Linux)>`__ can also be used. Set " "``images_volume_group = nova_local`` where ``nova_local`` is the name of the " "LVM group you have created." msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-kvm.rst:253 msgid "Specify the CPU model of KVM guests" msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-kvm.rst:255 msgid "" "The Compute service enables you to control the guest CPU model that is " "exposed to KVM virtual machines. Use cases include:" msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-kvm.rst:258 msgid "" "To maximize performance of virtual machines by exposing new host CPU " "features to the guest" msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-kvm.rst:260 msgid "" "To ensure a consistent default CPU across all machines, removing reliance of " "variable QEMU defaults" msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-kvm.rst:263 msgid "" "In libvirt, the CPU is specified by providing a base CPU model name (which " "is a shorthand for a set of feature flags), a set of additional feature " "flags, and the topology (sockets/cores/threads). The libvirt KVM driver " "provides a number of standard CPU model names. These models are defined in " "the ``/usr/share/libvirt/cpu_map.xml`` file. Check this file to determine " "which models are supported by your local installation." msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-kvm.rst:271 msgid "" "Two Compute configuration options in the ``[libvirt]`` group of ``nova." "conf`` define which type of CPU model is exposed to the hypervisor when " "using KVM: ``cpu_mode`` and ``cpu_model``." msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-kvm.rst:275 msgid "" "The ``cpu_mode`` option can take one of the following values: ``none``, " "``host-passthrough``, ``host-model``, and ``custom``." msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-kvm.rst:279 msgid "Host model (default for KVM & QEMU)" msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-kvm.rst:281 msgid "" "If your ``nova.conf`` file contains ``cpu_mode=host-model``, libvirt " "identifies the CPU model in ``/usr/share/libvirt/cpu_map.xml`` file that " "most closely matches the host, and requests additional CPU flags to complete " "the match. This configuration provides the maximum functionality and " "performance and maintains good reliability and compatibility if the guest is " "migrated to another host with slightly different host CPUs." msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-kvm.rst:289 msgid "Host pass through" msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-kvm.rst:291 msgid "" "If your ``nova.conf`` file contains ``cpu_mode=host-passthrough``, libvirt " "tells KVM to pass through the host CPU with no modifications. The difference " "to host-model, instead of just matching feature flags, every last detail of " "the host CPU is matched. This gives the best performance, and can be " "important to some apps which check low level CPU details, but it comes at a " "cost with respect to migration. The guest can only be migrated to a matching " "host CPU." msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-kvm.rst:300 msgid "Custom" msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-kvm.rst:302 msgid "" "If your ``nova.conf`` file contains ``cpu_mode=custom``, you can explicitly " "specify one of the supported named models using the cpu_model configuration " "option. For example, to configure the KVM guests to expose Nehalem CPUs, " "your ``nova.conf`` file should contain:" msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-kvm.rst:314 msgid "None (default for all libvirt-driven hypervisors other than KVM & QEMU)" msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-kvm.rst:316 msgid "" "If your ``nova.conf`` file contains ``cpu_mode=none``, libvirt does not " "specify a CPU model. Instead, the hypervisor chooses the default model." msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-kvm.rst:320 msgid "Guest agent support" msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-kvm.rst:322 msgid "" "Use guest agents to enable optional access between compute nodes and guests " "through a socket, using the QMP protocol." msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-kvm.rst:325 msgid "" "To enable this feature, you must set ``hw_qemu_guest_agent=yes`` as a " "metadata parameter on the image you wish to use to create the guest-agent-" "capable instances from. You can explicitly disable the feature by setting " "``hw_qemu_guest_agent=no`` in the image metadata." msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-kvm.rst:331 msgid "KVM performance tweaks" msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-kvm.rst:333 msgid "" "The `VHostNet <http://www.linux-kvm.org/page/VhostNet>`_ kernel module " "improves network performance. To load the kernel module, run the following " "command as root:" msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-kvm.rst:342 msgid "Troubleshoot KVM" msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-kvm.rst:344 msgid "" "Trying to launch a new virtual machine instance fails with the ``ERROR`` " "state, and the following error appears in the ``/var/log/nova/nova-compute." "log`` file:" msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-kvm.rst:352 msgid "This message indicates that the KVM kernel modules were not loaded." msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-kvm.rst:354 msgid "" "If you cannot start VMs after installation without rebooting, the " "permissions might not be set correctly. This can happen if you load the KVM " "module before you install ``nova-compute``. To check whether the group is " "set to ``kvm``, run:" msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-kvm.rst:363 msgid "If it is not set to ``kvm``, run:" msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-lxc.rst:3 msgid "LXC (Linux containers)" msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-lxc.rst:5 msgid "" "LXC (also known as Linux containers) is a virtualization technology that " "works at the operating system level. This is different from hardware " "virtualization, the approach used by other hypervisors such as KVM, Xen, and " "VMware. LXC (as currently implemented using libvirt in the Compute service) " "is not a secure virtualization technology for multi-tenant environments " "(specifically, containers may affect resource quotas for other containers " "hosted on the same machine). Additional containment technologies, such as " "AppArmor, may be used to provide better isolation between containers, " "although this is not the case by default. For all these reasons, the choice " "of this virtualization technology is not recommended in production." msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-lxc.rst:17 msgid "" "If your compute hosts do not have hardware support for virtualization, LXC " "will likely provide better performance than QEMU. In addition, if your " "guests must access specialized hardware, such as GPUs, this might be easier " "to achieve with LXC than other hypervisors." msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-lxc.rst:24 msgid "" "Some OpenStack Compute features might be missing when running with LXC as " "the hypervisor. See the `hypervisor support matrix <http://wiki.openstack." "org/HypervisorSupportMatrix>`_ for details." msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-lxc.rst:28 msgid "" "To enable LXC, ensure the following options are set in ``/etc/nova/nova." "conf`` on all hosts running the ``nova-compute`` service." msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-lxc.rst:38 msgid "" "On Ubuntu, enable LXC support in OpenStack by installing the ``nova-compute-" "lxc`` package." msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-qemu.rst:5 msgid "QEMU" msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-qemu.rst:7 msgid "" "From the perspective of the Compute service, the QEMU hypervisor is very " "similar to the KVM hypervisor. Both are controlled through libvirt, both " "support the same feature set, and all virtual machine images that are " "compatible with KVM are also compatible with QEMU. The main difference is " "that QEMU does not support native virtualization. Consequently, QEMU has " "worse performance than KVM and is a poor choice for a production deployment." msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-qemu.rst:15 msgid "The typical uses cases for QEMU are" msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-qemu.rst:17 msgid "Running on older hardware that lacks virtualization support." msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-qemu.rst:18 msgid "" "Running the Compute service inside of a virtual machine for development or " "testing purposes, where the hypervisor does not support native " "virtualization for guests." msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-qemu.rst:22 msgid "To enable QEMU, add these settings to ``nova.conf``:" msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-qemu.rst:31 msgid "" "For some operations you may also have to install the :command:`guestmount` " "utility:" msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-qemu.rst:40 msgid "On Red Hat Enterprise Linux, Fedora, or CentOS:" msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-qemu.rst:52 msgid "" "The QEMU hypervisor supports the following virtual machine image formats:" msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-vmware.rst:0 msgid "OpenStack Image service OS type settings" msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-vmware.rst:0 msgid "OpenStack Image service disk type settings" msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-vmware.rst:0 msgid "vCenter permissions tree" msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-vmware.rst:3 msgid "VMware vSphere" msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-vmware.rst:8 msgid "" "OpenStack Compute supports the VMware vSphere product family and enables " "access to advanced features such as vMotion, High Availability, and Dynamic " "Resource Scheduling (DRS)." msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-vmware.rst:12 msgid "" "This section describes how to configure VMware-based virtual machine images " "for launch. The VMware driver supports vCenter version 5.1.0 and later." msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-vmware.rst:15 msgid "" "The VMware vCenter driver enables the ``nova-compute`` service to " "communicate with a VMware vCenter server that manages one or more ESX host " "clusters. The driver aggregates the ESX hosts in each cluster to present one " "large hypervisor entity for each cluster to the Compute scheduler. Because " "individual ESX hosts are not exposed to the scheduler, Compute schedules to " "the granularity of clusters and vCenter uses DRS to select the actual ESX " "host within the cluster. When a virtual machine makes its way into a vCenter " "cluster, it can use all vSphere features." msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-vmware.rst:24 msgid "" "The following sections describe how to configure the VMware vCenter driver." msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-vmware.rst:27 msgid "High-level architecture" msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-vmware.rst:29 msgid "" "The following diagram shows a high-level view of the VMware driver " "architecture:" msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-vmware.rst:32 msgid "**VMware driver architecture**" msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-vmware.rst:37 msgid "" "As the figure shows, the OpenStack Compute Scheduler sees three hypervisors " "that each correspond to a cluster in vCenter. ``nova-compute`` contains the " "VMware driver. You can run with multiple ``nova-compute`` services. While " "Compute schedules at the granularity of a cluster, the VMware driver inside " "``nova-compute`` interacts with the vCenter APIs to select an appropriate " "ESX host within the cluster. Internally, vCenter uses DRS for placement." msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-vmware.rst:45 msgid "" "The VMware vCenter driver also interacts with the Image service to copy VMDK " "images from the Image service back-end store. The dotted line in the figure " "represents VMDK images being copied from the OpenStack Image service to the " "vSphere data store. VMDK images are cached in the data store so the copy " "operation is only required the first time that the VMDK image is used." msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-vmware.rst:52 msgid "" "After OpenStack boots a VM into a vSphere cluster, the VM becomes visible in " "vCenter and can access vSphere advanced features. At the same time, the VM " "is visible in the OpenStack dashboard and you can manage it as you would any " "other OpenStack VM. You can perform advanced vSphere operations in vCenter " "while you configure OpenStack resources such as VMs through the OpenStack " "dashboard." msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-vmware.rst:59 msgid "" "The figure does not show how networking fits into the architecture. Both " "``nova-network`` and the OpenStack Networking Service are supported. For " "details, see :ref:`vmware-networking`." msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-vmware.rst:64 msgid "Configuration overview" msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-vmware.rst:66 msgid "" "To get started with the VMware vCenter driver, complete the following high-" "level steps:" msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-vmware.rst:69 msgid "Configure vCenter. See :ref:`vmware-prereqs`." msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-vmware.rst:70 msgid "" "Configure the VMware vCenter driver in the ``nova.conf`` file. See :ref:" "`vmware-vcdriver`." msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-vmware.rst:72 msgid "" "Load desired VMDK images into the Image service. See :ref:`vmware-images`." msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-vmware.rst:73 msgid "" "Configure networking with either ``nova-network`` or the Networking service. " "See :ref:`vmware-networking`." msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-vmware.rst:79 msgid "Prerequisites and limitations" msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-vmware.rst:81 msgid "" "Use the following list to prepare a vSphere environment that runs with the " "VMware vCenter driver:" msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-vmware.rst:85 msgid "" "In vSphere 5.1, copying large image files (for example, 12 GB and greater) " "from the Image service can take a long time. To improve performance, VMware " "recommends that you upgrade to VMware vCenter Server 5.1 Update 1 or later. " "For more information, see the `Release Notes <https://www.vmware.com/support/" "vsphere5/doc/ vsphere-vcenter-server-51u1-release-notes." "html#resolvedissuescimapi>`_." msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-vmware.rst:90 msgid "Copying VMDK files" msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-vmware.rst:93 msgid "" "For any cluster that contains multiple ESX hosts, enable DRS and enable " "fully automated placement." msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-vmware.rst:94 msgid "DRS" msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-vmware.rst:97 msgid "" "Only shared storage is supported and data stores must be shared among all " "hosts in a cluster. It is recommended to remove data stores not intended for " "OpenStack from clusters being configured for OpenStack." msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-vmware.rst:99 msgid "Shared storage" msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-vmware.rst:102 msgid "" "Do not use OpenStack clusters and data stores for other purposes. If you do, " "OpenStack displays incorrect usage information." msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-vmware.rst:103 msgid "Clusters and data stores" msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-vmware.rst:106 msgid "" "The networking configuration depends on the desired networking model. See :" "ref:`vmware-networking`." msgstr "" # #-#-#-#-# compute.pot (Configuration Reference 0.9) #-#-#-#-# # #-#-#-#-# networking.pot (Configuration Reference 0.9) #-#-#-#-# #: ../compute/hypervisor-vmware.rst:107 ../networking.rst:3 msgid "Networking" msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-vmware.rst:110 msgid "" "If you use the VMware driver with OpenStack Networking and the NSX plug-in, " "security groups are supported. If you use ``nova-network``, security groups " "are not supported." msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-vmware.rst:116 msgid "Security groups" msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-vmware.rst:116 msgid "The NSX plug-in is the only plug-in that is validated for vSphere." msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-vmware.rst:119 msgid "" "The port range 5900 - 6105 (inclusive) is automatically enabled for VNC " "connections on every ESX host in all clusters under OpenStack control." msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-vmware.rst:124 msgid "" "In addition to the default VNC port numbers (5900 to 6000) specified in the " "above document, the following ports are also used: 6101, 6102, and 6105." msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-vmware.rst:128 msgid "" "You must modify the ESXi firewall configuration to allow the VNC ports. " "Additionally, for the firewall modifications to persist after a reboot, you " "must create a custom vSphere Installation Bundle (VIB) which is then " "installed onto the running ESXi host or added to a custom image profile used " "to install ESXi hosts. For details about how to create a VIB for persisting " "the firewall configuration modifications, see http://kb.vmware.com/" "selfservice/microsites/search.do?language=en_US&cmd=displayKC&" "externalId=2007381." msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-vmware.rst:138 msgid "" "The VIB can be downloaded from https://github.com/openstack-vmwareapi-team/" "Tools." msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-vmware.rst:139 msgid "VNC" msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-vmware.rst:141 msgid "" "To use multiple vCenter installations with OpenStack, each vCenter must be " "assigned to a separate availability zone. This is required as the OpenStack " "Block Storage VMDK driver does not currently work across multiple vCenter " "installations." msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-vmware.rst:147 msgid "VMware vCenter service account" msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-vmware.rst:149 msgid "" "OpenStack integration requires a vCenter service account with the following " "minimum permissions. ../compute/hypervisor-vmware.rst:397 msgid "VMware vCenter driver" msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-vmware.rst:399 msgid "" "Use the VMware vCenter driver (VMwareVCDriver) to connect OpenStack Compute " "with vCenter. This recommended configuration enables access through vCenter " "to advanced vSphere features like vMotion, High Availability, and Dynamic " "Resource Scheduling (DRS)." msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-vmware.rst:405 msgid "VMwareVCDriver configuration options" msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-vmware.rst:407 msgid "" "When you use the VMwareVCDriver (vCenter versions 5.1 and later) with " "OpenStack Compute, add the following VMware-specific configuration options " "to the ``nova.conf`` file:" msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-vmware.rst:425 msgid "" "vSphere vCenter versions 5.0 and earlier: You must specify the location of " "the WSDL files by adding the ``wsdl_location=http://127.0.0.1:8080/vmware/" "SDK/wsdl/vim25/vimService.wsdl`` setting to the above configuration." msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-vmware.rst:430 msgid "" "Clusters: The vCenter driver can support only a single cluster. Clusters and " "data stores used by the vCenter driver should not contain any VMs other than " "those created by the driver." msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-vmware.rst:434 msgid "" "Data stores: The ``datastore_regex`` setting specifies the data stores to " "use with Compute. For example, ``datastore_regex="nas.*"`` selects all " "the data stores that have a name starting with "nas". If this line is " "omitted, Compute uses the first data store returned by the vSphere API. It " "is recommended not to use this field and instead remove data stores that are " "not intended for OpenStack." msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-vmware.rst:441 msgid "" "Reserved host memory: The ``reserved_host_memory_mb`` option value is 512 MB " "by default. However, VMware recommends that you set this option to 0 MB " "because the vCenter driver reports the effective memory available to the " "virtual machines." msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-vmware.rst:446 msgid "" "The vCenter driver generates instance name by instance ID. Instance name " "template is ignored." msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-vmware.rst:449 msgid "" "The minimum supported vCenter version is 5.1.0. In OpenStack Liberty release " "this will be logged as a warning. In OpenStack Mitaka release this will be " "enforced." msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-vmware.rst:453 msgid "" "A ``nova-compute`` service can control one or more clusters containing " "multiple ESXi hosts, making ``nova-compute`` a critical service from a high " "availability perspective. Because the host that runs ``nova-compute`` can " "fail while the vCenter and ESX still run, you must protect the ``nova-" "compute`` service against host failures." msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-vmware.rst:461 msgid "" "Many ``nova.conf`` options are relevant to libvirt but do not apply to this " "driver." msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-vmware.rst:464 msgid "" "You must complete additional configuration for environments that use vSphere " "5.0 and earlier. See `vSphere 5.0 and earlier additional set up <http://docs." "openstack.org/liberty/config-reference/content/vmware." "html#VMware_additional_config>`_ available in previous released documents." msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-vmware.rst:472 msgid "Images with VMware vSphere" msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-vmware.rst:474 msgid "" "The vCenter driver supports images in the VMDK format. Disks in this format " "can be obtained from VMware Fusion or from an ESX environment. It is also " "possible to convert other formats, such as qcow2, to the VMDK format using " "the ``qemu-img`` utility. After a VMDK disk is available, load it into the " "Image service. Then, you can use it with the VMware vCenter driver. The " "following sections provide additional details on the supported disks and the " "commands used for conversion and upload." msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-vmware.rst:483 msgid "Supported image types" msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-vmware.rst:485 msgid "" "Upload images to the OpenStack Image service in VMDK format. The following " "VMDK disk types are supported:" msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-vmware.rst:488 msgid "" "``VMFS Flat Disks`` (includes thin, thick, zeroedthick, and " "eagerzeroedthick). Note that once a VMFS thin disk is exported from VMFS to " "a non-VMFS location, like the OpenStack Image service, it becomes a " "preallocated flat disk. This impacts the transfer time from the Image " "service to the data store when the full preallocated flat disk, rather than " "the thin disk, must be transferred." msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-vmware.rst:495 msgid "" "``Monolithic Sparse disks``. Sparse disks get imported from the Image " "service into ESXi as thin provisioned disks. Monolithic Sparse disks can be " "obtained from VMware Fusion or can be created by converting from other " "virtual disk formats using the ``qemu-img`` utility." msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-vmware.rst:500 msgid "" "``Stream-optimized disks``. Stream-optimized disks are compressed sparse " "disks. They can be obtained from VMware vCenter/ESXi when exporting vm to " "ovf/ova template." msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-vmware.rst:504 msgid "" "The following table shows the ``vmware_disktype`` property that applies to " "each of the supported VMDK disk types:" msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-vmware.rst:510 msgid "vmware_disktype property" msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-vmware.rst:512 msgid "sparse" msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-vmware.rst:513 msgid "Monolithic Sparse" msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-vmware.rst:515 msgid "VMFS flat, thin provisioned" msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-vmware.rst:516 msgid "preallocated (default)" msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-vmware.rst:517 msgid "VMFS flat, thick/zeroedthick/eagerzeroedthick" msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-vmware.rst:518 msgid "Streamoptimized" msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-vmware.rst:519 msgid "Compressed Sparse" msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-vmware.rst:521 msgid "" "The ``vmware_disktype`` property is set when an image is loaded into the " "Image service. For example, the following command creates a Monolithic " "Sparse image by setting ``vmware_disktype`` to ``sparse``:" msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-vmware.rst:534 msgid "" "Specifying ``thin`` does not provide any advantage over ``preallocated`` " "with the current version of the driver. Future versions might restore the " "thin properties of the disk after it is downloaded to a vSphere data store." msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-vmware.rst:539 msgid "" "The following table shows msgid "" "Using the ``qemu-img`` utility, disk images in several formats (such as, " "qcow2) can be converted to the VMDK format." msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-vmware.rst:734 msgid "" "For example, the following command can be used to convert a `qcow2 Ubuntu " "Trusty cloud image <http://cloud-images.ubuntu.com/trusty/ current/trusty-" "server-cloudimg-amd64-disk1.img>`_:" msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-vmware.rst:743 msgid "" "VMDK disks converted through ``qemu-img`` are ``always`` monolithic sparse " "VMDK disks with an IDE adapter type. Using the previous example of the " "Ubuntu Trusty image after the ``qemu-img`` conversion, the command to upload " "the VMDK disk should be something like:" msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-vmware.rst:756 msgid "" "Note that the ``vmware_disktype`` is set to ``sparse`` and the " "``vmware_adaptertype`` is set to ``ide`` in the previous command." msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-vmware.rst:759 msgid "" "If the image did not come from the ``qemu-img`` utility, the " "``vmware_disktype`` and ``vmware_adaptertype`` might be different. To " "determine the image adapter type from an image file, use the following " "command and look for the ``ddb.adapterType=`` line:" msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-vmware.rst:768 msgid "" "Assuming a preallocated disk type and an iSCSI lsiLogic adapter type, the " "following command uploads the VMDK disk:" msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-vmware.rst:779 msgid "" "Currently, OS boot VMDK disks with an IDE adapter type cannot be attached to " "a virtual SCSI controller and likewise disks with one of the SCSI adapter " "types (such as, busLogic, lsiLogic, lsiLogicsas, paraVirtual) cannot be " "attached to the IDE controller. Therefore, as the previous examples show, it " "is important to set the ``vmware_adaptertype`` property correctly. The " "default adapter type is lsiLogic, which is SCSI, so you can omit the " "``vmware_adaptertype`` property if you are certain that the image adapter " "type is lsiLogic." msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-vmware.rst:789 msgid "Tag VMware images" msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-vmware.rst:791 msgid "" "In a mixed hypervisor environment, OpenStack Compute uses the " "``hypervisor_type`` tag to match images to the correct hypervisor type. For " "VMware images, set the hypervisor type to ``vmware``. Other valid hypervisor " "types include: ``hyperv``, ``ironic``, ``lxc``, ``qemu``, ``uml``, and " "``xen``. Note that ``qemu`` is used for both QEMU and KVM hypervisor types." msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-vmware.rst:808 msgid "Optimize images" msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-vmware.rst:810 msgid "" "Monolithic Sparse disks are considerably faster to download but have the " "overhead of an additional conversion step. When imported into ESX, sparse " "disks get converted to VMFS flat thin provisioned disks. The download and " "conversion steps only affect the first launched instance that uses the " "sparse disk image. The converted disk image is cached, so subsequent " "instances that use this disk image can simply use the cached version." msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-vmware.rst:817 msgid "" "To avoid the conversion step (at the cost of longer download times) consider " "converting sparse disks to thin provisioned or preallocated disks before " "loading them into the Image service." msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-vmware.rst:821 msgid "Use one of the following tools to pre-convert sparse disks." msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-vmware.rst:824 msgid "Sometimes called the remote CLI or rCLI." msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-vmware.rst:826 msgid "" "Assuming that the sparse disk is made available on a data store accessible " "by an ESX host, the following command converts it to preallocated format:" msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-vmware.rst:835 msgid "" "Note that the vifs tool from the same CLI package can be used to upload the " "disk to be converted. The vifs tool can also be used to download the " "converted disk if necessary." msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-vmware.rst:837 msgid "vSphere CLI tools" msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-vmware.rst:840 msgid "" "If the SSH service is enabled on an ESX host, the sparse disk can be " "uploaded to the ESX data store through scp and the vmkfstools local to the " "ESX host can use used to perform the conversion. After you log in to the " "host through ssh, run this command:" msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-vmware.rst:847 msgid "vmkfstools directly on the ESX host" msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-vmware.rst:850 msgid "" "``vmware-vdiskmanager`` is a utility that comes bundled with VMware Fusion " "and VMware Workstation. The following example converts a sparse disk to " "preallocated format:" msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-vmware.rst:856 msgid "vmware-vdiskmanager" msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-vmware.rst:858 msgid "In the previous cases, the converted vmdk is actually a pair of files:" msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-vmware.rst:860 msgid "The descriptor file ``converted.vmdk``." msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-vmware.rst:861 msgid "The actual virtual disk data file ``converted-flat.vmdk``." msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-vmware.rst:863 msgid "" "The file to be uploaded to the Image service is ``converted-flat.vmdk``." msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-vmware.rst:866 msgid "Image handling" msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-vmware.rst:868 msgid "" "The ESX hypervisor requires a copy of the VMDK file in order to boot up a " "virtual machine. As a result, the vCenter OpenStack Compute driver must " "download the VMDK via HTTP from the Image service to a data store that is " "visible to the hypervisor. To optimize this process, the first time a VMDK " "file is used, it gets cached in the data store. A cached image is stored in " "a folder named after the image ID. Subsequent virtual machines that need the " "VMDK use the cached version and don't have to copy the file again from the " "Image service." msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-vmware.rst:877 msgid "" "Even with a cached VMDK, there is still a copy operation from the cache " "location to the hypervisor file directory in the shared data store. To avoid " "this copy, boot the image in linked_clone mode. To learn how to enable this " "mode, see :ref:`vmware-config`." msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-vmware.rst:884 msgid "" "You can also use the ``vmware_linked_clone`` property in the Image service " "to override the linked_clone mode on a per-image basis." msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-vmware.rst:887 msgid "" "If spawning a virtual machine image from ISO with a VMDK disk, the image is " "created and attached to the virtual machine as a blank disk. In that case " "``vmware_linked_clone`` property for the image is just ignored." msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-vmware.rst:891 msgid "" "If multiple compute nodes are running on the same host, or have a shared " "file system, you can enable them to use the same cache folder on the back-" "end data store. To configure this action, set the ``cache_prefix`` option in " "the ``nova.conf`` file. Its value stands for the name prefix of the folder " "where cached images are stored." msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-vmware.rst:899 msgid "" "This can take effect only if compute nodes are running on the same host, or " "have a shared file system." msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-vmware.rst:902 msgid "" "You can automatically purge unused images after a specified period of time. " "To configure this action, set these options in the ``DEFAULT`` section in " "the ``nova.conf`` file:" msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-vmware.rst:907 msgid "" "Set this option to ``True`` to specify that unused images should be removed " "after the duration specified in the " "``remove_unused_original_minimum_age_seconds`` option. The default is " "``True``." msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-vmware.rst:910 msgid "remove_unused_base_images" msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-vmware.rst:913 msgid "" "Specifies the duration in seconds after which an unused image is purged from " "the cache. The default is ``86400`` (24 hours)." msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-vmware.rst:914 msgid "remove_unused_original_minimum_age_seconds" msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-vmware.rst:919 msgid "Networking with VMware vSphere" msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-vmware.rst:921 msgid "" "The VMware driver supports networking with the ``nova-network`` service or " "the Networking Service. Depending on your installation, complete these " "configuration steps before you provision VMs:" msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-vmware.rst:925 msgid "" "**The nova-network service with the FlatManager or FlatDHCPManager**. Create " "a port group with the same name as the ``flat_network_bridge`` value in the " "``nova.conf`` file. The default value is ``br100``. If you specify another " "value, the new value must be a valid Linux bridge identifier that adheres to " "Linux bridge naming conventions." msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-vmware.rst:931 msgid "All VM NICs are attached to this port group." msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-vmware.rst:933 msgid "" "Ensure that the flat interface of the node that runs the ``nova-network`` " "service has a path to this network." msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-vmware.rst:938 msgid "" "When configuring the port binding for this port group in vCenter, specify " "``ephemeral`` for the port binding type. For more information, see `Choosing " "a port binding type in ESX/ESXi <http://kb.vmware.com/ selfservice/" "microsites/search.do?language=en_US&cmd=displayKC &" "externalId=1022312>`_ in the VMware Knowledge Base." msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-vmware.rst:944 msgid "" "**The nova-network service with the VlanManager**. Set the " "``vlan_interface`` configuration option to match the ESX host interface that " "handles VLAN-tagged VM traffic." msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-vmware.rst:948 msgid "OpenStack Compute automatically creates the corresponding port groups." msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-vmware.rst:950 msgid "" "If you are using the OpenStack Networking Service: Before provisioning VMs, " "create a port group with the same name as the ``vmware.integration_bridge`` " "value in ``nova.conf`` (default is ``br-int``). All VM NICs are attached to " "this port group for management by the OpenStack Networking plug-in." msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-vmware.rst:957 msgid "Volumes with VMware vSphere" msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-vmware.rst:959 msgid "" "The VMware driver supports attaching volumes from the Block Storage service. " "The VMware VMDK driver for OpenStack Block Storage is recommended and should " "be used for managing volumes based on vSphere data stores. For more " "information about the VMware VMDK driver, see :ref:" "`block_storage_vmdk_driver`. Also an iSCSI volume driver provides limited " "support and can be used only for attachments." msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-vmware.rst:971 msgid "" "To customize the VMware driver, use the configuration option settings " "documented in :ref:`nova-vmware`." msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-xen-api.rst:5 msgid "XenServer (and other XAPI based Xen variants)" msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-xen-api.rst:7 msgid "" "This section describes XAPI managed hypervisors, and how to use them with " "OpenStack." msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-xen-api.rst:11 msgid "Terminology" msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-xen-api.rst:14 msgid "Xen" msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-xen-api.rst:16 msgid "" "A hypervisor that provides the fundamental isolation between virtual " "machines. Xen is open source (GPLv2) and is managed by `XenProject.org " "<http://www.xenproject.org>`_, a cross-industry organization and a Linux " "Foundation Collaborative project." msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-xen-api.rst:21 msgid "" "Xen is a component of many different products and projects. The hypervisor " "itself is very similar across all these projects, but the way that it is " "managed can be different, which can cause confusion if you're not clear " "which toolstack you are using. Make sure you know what `toolstack <http://" "wiki.xen.org/wiki/Choice_of_Toolstacks>`_ you want before you get started. " "If you want to use Xen with libvirt in OpenStack Compute refer to :doc:" "`hypervisor-xen-libvirt`." msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-xen-api.rst:31 msgid "XAPI" msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-xen-api.rst:33 msgid "" "XAPI is one of the toolstacks that could control a Xen based hypervisor. " "XAPI's role is similar to libvirt's in the KVM world. The API provided by " "XAPI is called XenAPI. To learn more about the provided interface, look at " "`XenAPI Object Model Overview <http://docs.vmd.citrix.com/XenServer/ " "6.2.0/1.0/en_gb/sdk.html#object_model_overview>`_ for definitions of XAPI " "specific terms such as SR, VDI, VIF and PIF." msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-xen-api.rst:41 msgid "" "OpenStack has a compute driver which talks to XAPI, therefore all XAPI " "managed servers could be used with OpenStack." msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-xen-api.rst:45 msgid "XenAPI" msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-xen-api.rst:47 msgid "" "XenAPI is the API provided by XAPI. This name is also used by the python " "library that is a client for XAPI." msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-xen-api.rst:51 ../compute/resize.rst:23 msgid "XenServer" msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-xen-api.rst:53 msgid "" "An Open Source virtualization platform that delivers all features needed for " "any server and datacenter implementation including the Xen hypervisor and " "XAPI for the management. For more information and product downloads, visit " "`xenserver.org <http://xenserver.org/>`_." msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-xen-api.rst:59 msgid "XCP" msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-xen-api.rst:61 msgid "" "XCP is not supported anymore. XCP project recommends all XCP users to " "upgrade to the latest version of XenServer by visiting `xenserver.org " "<http://xenserver.org/>`_." msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-xen-api.rst:66 msgid "XenServer-core" msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-xen-api.rst:68 msgid "" "This is a method for building the core packages in a XenServer installation " "on an existing RPM-based system. Initial support for this configuration " "(notably running Compute services in domain 0) was added in Havana. " "XenServer-core for Debian/Ubuntu is built from the main branch and, " "therefore, is continuously up to date." msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-xen-api.rst:75 msgid "Kronos" msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-xen-api.rst:77 msgid "" "This is a project initiated to provide the ability to install XAPI toolstack " "onto an existing Debian-based deployment. For more information, visit the " "`Xen wiki Project Kronos <http://wiki.xenproject.org/wiki/Project_Kronos>`_." msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-xen-api.rst:83 msgid "Privileged and unprivileged domains" msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-xen-api.rst:85 msgid "" "A Xen host runs a number of virtual machines, VMs, or domains (the terms are " "synonymous on Xen). One of these is in charge of running the rest of the " "system, and is known as domain 0, or dom0. It is the first domain to boot " "after Xen, and owns the storage and networking hardware, the device drivers, " "and the primary control software. Any other VM is unprivileged, and is known " "as a domU or guest. All customer VMs are unprivileged, but you should note " "that on Xen, the OpenStack Compute service (``nova-compute``) also runs in a " "domU. This gives a level of security isolation between the privileged system " "software and the OpenStack software (much of which is customer-facing). This " "architecture is described in more detail later." msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-xen-api.rst:99 msgid "Paravirtualized versus hardware virtualized domains" msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-xen-api.rst:101 msgid "" "A Xen virtual machine can be paravirtualized (PV) or hardware virtualized " "(HVM). This refers to the interaction between Xen, domain 0, and the guest " "VM's kernel. PV guests are aware of the fact that they are virtualized and " "will co-operate with Xen and domain 0; this gives them better performance " "characteristics. HVM guests are not aware of their environment, and the " "hardware has to pretend that they are running on an unvirtualized machine. " "HVM guests do not need to modify the guest operating system, which is " "essential when running Windows." msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-xen-api.rst:111 msgid "" "In OpenStack, customer VMs may run in either PV or HVM mode. However, the " "OpenStack domU (that's the one running ``nova-compute``) must be running in " "PV mode." msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-xen-api.rst:116 msgid "XenAPI deployment architecture" msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-xen-api.rst:118 msgid "" "A basic OpenStack deployment on a XAPI-managed server, assuming that the " "network provider is nova-network, looks like this:" msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-xen-api.rst:124 msgid "Key things to note:" msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-xen-api.rst:126 msgid "The hypervisor: Xen" msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-xen-api.rst:127 msgid "" "Domain 0: runs XAPI and some small pieces from OpenStack, the XAPI plug-ins." msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-xen-api.rst:129 msgid "" "OpenStack VM: The ``Compute`` service runs in a paravirtualized virtual " "machine, on the host under management. Each host runs a local instance of " "``Compute``. It is also running an instance of nova-network." msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-xen-api.rst:133 msgid "" "OpenStack Compute uses the XenAPI Python library to talk to XAPI, and it " "uses the Management Network to reach from the OpenStack VM to Domain 0." msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-xen-api.rst:136 msgid "Some notes on the networking:" msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-xen-api.rst:138 msgid "The above diagram assumes FlatDHCP networking." msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-xen-api.rst:139 msgid "There are three main OpenStack networks:" msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-xen-api.rst:141 msgid "" "Management network: RabbitMQ, MySQL, inter-host communication, and compute-" "XAPI communication. Please note that the VM images are downloaded by the " "XenAPI plug-ins, so make sure that the OpenStack Image service is accessible " "through this network. It usually means binding those services to the " "management interface." msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-xen-api.rst:146 msgid "" "Tenant network: controlled by nova-network, this is used for tenant traffic." msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-xen-api.rst:148 msgid "Public network: floating IPs, public API endpoints." msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-xen-api.rst:150 msgid "" "The networks shown here must be connected to the corresponding physical " "networks within the data center. In the simplest case, three individual " "physical network cards could be used. It is also possible to use VLANs to " "separate these networks. Please note, that the selected configuration must " "be in line with the networking model selected for the cloud. (In case of " "VLAN networking, the physical channels have to be able to forward the tagged " "traffic.)" msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-xen-api.rst:159 msgid "Further reading" msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-xen-api.rst:161 msgid "Here are some of the resources available to learn more about Xen:" msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-xen-api.rst:163 msgid "" "`Citrix XenServer official documentation <http://docs.vmd.citrix.com/" "XenServer/6.2.0/1.0/en_gb/>`_" msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-xen-api.rst:165 msgid "" "`What is Xen? by XenProject.org <http://www.xenproject.org/users/cloud." "html>`_" msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-xen-api.rst:167 msgid "" "`Xen Hypervisor project <http://www.xenproject.org/developers/teams/" "hypervisor.html>`_" msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-xen-api.rst:169 msgid "`Xapi project <http://www.xenproject.org/developers/teams/xapi.html>`_" msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-xen-api.rst:170 msgid "" "`Further XenServer and OpenStack information <http://wiki.openstack.org/" "XenServer>`_" msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-xen-api.rst:174 msgid "Install XenServer" msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-xen-api.rst:176 msgid "" "Before you can run OpenStack with XenServer, you must install the hypervisor " "on `an appropriate server <http://docs.vmd.citrix.com/XenServer/ 6.2.0/1.0/" "en_gb/installation.html#sys_requirements>`_." msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-xen-api.rst:182 msgid "" "Xen is a type 1 hypervisor: When your server starts, Xen is the first " "software that runs. Consequently, you must install XenServer before you " "install the operating system where you want to run OpenStack code. You then " "install ``nova-compute`` into a dedicated virtual machine on the host." msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-xen-api.rst:187 msgid "Use the following link to download XenServer's installation media:" msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-xen-api.rst:189 msgid "http://xenserver.org/open-source-virtualization-download.html" msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-xen-api.rst:191 msgid "" "When you install many servers, you might find it easier to perform `PXE boot " "installations <http://docs.vmd.citrix.com/XenServer/6.2.0/ 1.0/en_gb/" "installation.html#pxe_boot_install>`_. You can also package any post-" "installation changes that you want to make to your XenServer by following " "the instructions of `creating your own XenServer supplemental pack <http://" "docs.vmd.citrix.com/ XenServer/6.2.0/1.0/en_gb/supplemental_pack_ddk.html>`_." msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-xen-api.rst:201 msgid "" "Make sure you use the EXT type of storage repository (SR). Features that " "require access to VHD files (such as copy on write, snapshot and migration) " "do not work when you use the LVM SR. Storage repository (SR) is a XAPI-" "specific term relating to the physical storage where virtual disks are " "stored." msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-xen-api.rst:207 msgid "" "On the XenServer installation screen, choose the :guilabel:`XenDesktop " "Optimized` option. If you use an answer file, make sure you use ``srtype=" ""ext"`` in the ``installation`` tag of the answer file." msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-xen-api.rst:212 msgid "Post-installation steps" msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-xen-api.rst:214 msgid "" "The following steps need to be completed after the hypervisor's installation:" msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-xen-api.rst:216 msgid "" "For resize and migrate functionality, enable password-less SSH " "authentication and set up the ``/images`` directory on dom0." msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-xen-api.rst:218 msgid "Install the XAPI plug-ins." msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-xen-api.rst:219 msgid "" "To support AMI type images, you must set up ``/boot/guest`` symlink/" "directory in dom0." msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-xen-api.rst:221 msgid "Create a paravirtualized virtual machine that can run ``nova-compute``." msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-xen-api.rst:222 msgid "Install and configure ``nova-compute`` in the above virtual machine." msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-xen-api.rst:225 msgid "Install XAPI plug-ins" msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-xen-api.rst:227 msgid "" "When you use a XAPI managed hypervisor, you can install a Python script (or " "any executable) on the host side, and execute that through XenAPI. These " "scripts are called plug-ins. The OpenStack related XAPI plug-ins live in " "OpenStack Compute's code repository. These plug-ins have to be copied to " "dom0's filesystem, to the appropriate directory, where XAPI can find them. " "It is important to ensure that the version of the plug-ins are in line with " "the OpenStack Compute installation you are using." msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-xen-api.rst:235 msgid "" "The plugins should typically be copied from the Nova installation running in " "the Compute's DomU, but if you want to download the latest version the " "following procedure can be used." msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-xen-api.rst:239 msgid "**Manually installing the plug-ins**" msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-xen-api.rst:241 msgid "Create temporary files/directories:" msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-xen-api.rst:248 msgid "" "Get the source from the openstack.org archives. The example assumes the " "master branch is used, and the XenServer host is accessible as xenserver. " "Match those parameters to your setup." msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-xen-api.rst:258 msgid "Copy the plug-ins to the hypervisor:" msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-xen-api.rst:266 msgid "Remove temporary files/directories:</para>" msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-xen-api.rst:274 msgid "Prepare for AMI type images" msgstr "" #: ../compute/hypervisor-xen-api.rst:276 msgid "" "To support AMI type images in your OpenStack installation, you must create " "the ``/boot/guest`` directory on dom0.
